column84: Insert text here No. Mandate Description Evidence/ comments about how this is achieved S1 End-to-End Encryption - All data in transit and at rest must be encrypted, in compliance with our policies. This applies to data within the SaaS platform, and the integration or access to Delta systems. Open encryption methodologies are used when communicating within our infrastructure and via public networks. The Jabra Xpress solution is only accessible using HTTPS on TLS (v1.2 as a minimum). Data at rest is encrypted using Microsoft Transparent Data Encryption (TDE - Transparent data encryption - Azure SQL Database & SQL Managed Instance & Azure Synapse Analytics. Microsoft Learn, with AES 256 as encryption algorithm). As a multi-tenant solution, the encryption key is shared for all customers, and it is not maintained by Jabra but Microsoft. S2 Authentication and Authorization S2.A: All Delta users must be authenticated by Global Auth, including MFA if required by Delta security standards. This requires a federated authentication integration with the SaaS provider. MFA is not available for customers currently and the access to the web service is done through username and password. Federated access is currently not available. S2.B: Credentials used for outbound APIs (i.e. Delta to SaaS provider) must be stored, controlled, and rotated in compliance with our Delta security standards. There are no APIs available for customers. The APIs currently in use are the ones required to communicate data from endpoints to our cloud service, which is done through a publicly available secure API. S2.C: All inbound APIs (i.e. SaaS provider to Delta) must be authorized using the Delta API Authorizer and must be processed through Akamai for our standard WAF and DDoS protection. There are no APIs available for customers. The APIs currently in use are the ones required to communicate data from endpoints to our cloud service, which is done through a publicly available secure API. S2.D: Access to the SaaS solution, and roles within the SaaS solution must be controlled using AD groups managed by SailPoint, unless there is evidence of technical reasons this cannot be achieved Currently, two different type of users are available - regular user and administrator, which is able to perform changes to Jabra Xpress customer own configuration. S2.E: Authorization controls within the SaaS solution must be managed to enforce least privilege. For example, general users should not have "tenant" admin privileges. Currently, two different type of users are available - regular user and administrator, which is able to perform changes to Jabra Xpress customer own configuration. Moreover, production environment and systems are only accessible to specific team members, following need to know and least privilege principles, and these are tracked together with their level of access. Likewise, all administrative actions are monitored and logged accordingly. S3 Cloud Access Security Broker - The SaaS solution must be integrated with the Delta CASB, unless there is evidence of technical reasons this cannot be achieved. Yes. S4 Direct Data Connections (this includes any direct data connectivity such as to databases, message queues, cache services, service bus, file systems, object stores, file transfers, etc.) S4.A: Inbound connections from the SaaS provider to Delta data sources directly via the Internet are not permitted. API, proxy, or other intermediary connectivity solutions must be included so the data sources do not need to be publicly accessible. Not applicable since Jabra Xpress is not pulling any data from Delta data sources. S4.B: Credentials used to authenticate all direct data traffic must be stored, controlled, and rotated in compliance with our Delta security standards. If this refers to JXO authenticating to Delta data sources, then this is also not applicable. S4.C: Data access controls, and data that is uploaded to the SaaS platform must be strictly limited to only the data necessary for the SaaS solution to function correctly. As by default, Jabra Xpress doesn't log any customer personal data (username and computer name). This option can be turned on and off by the customer -by default, it’s off-. In the case that the setting is turned on and then turned off, the data collected will be eventually deleted in 30 days if the device does not communicate with Xpress after that period. Data minimization is implemented in Jabra Xpress solution; hence, data actively collected (device list -inventory-, and analytics) are stored for 30 days. After that period, the data are deleted automatically if the device has not communicated with Xpress. All device-related information such as configuration, and user account information do not have an expiration and they are removed upon request as part of applicable privacy laws compliance. S5 Logging - The SaaS provider must offer logging or a way to view events for important transactions (e.g. logins, high-value transactions, administrative changes, etc.) Audit logs are accessible to certain authorized personnel, but these logs are not reviewed regularly for security events. The Jabra Xpress environment utilize the built-in Azure Application Insights resources (together with Azure Smart detection), to monitor elements such as: request, availability, and response time. Audit logs are available for 90 days. Both the SaaS solution and its logging system use the same Azure App Service for time sync (no real NTP server involved). S6 Restrict Network Access - The Delta tenant of the SaaS solution must only be accessible from the Delta network unless there is a business requirement to allow access from the public Internet. JXO UI solution is designed as a public web portal, allowing customers to sign in using their username and password. This portal is accessible over the Internet. Our solution is built using a multi-tenant architecture, where customers share resources in Azure. While data is isolated using unique identifiers, the network access remains open to accommodate the shared nature of the application.

column40:
​TechOps Avionics Engineering require a streamlined, secure, and efficient method to manage aircraft parts digitally. 

​Increasing complexity in aircraft systems and part certification demands a centralized platform for part validation, signing, and distribution. 

​The need to reduce manual processes and errors in part handling and logistics. 

​Fleet Link Parts enables digital workflows for importing, validating, signing, archiving, and exporting aircraft parts. 

​It supports secure digital signatures and trust chains for part authenticity.​
column41:
​​Reduced operational overhead by automating part validation, signing, and distribution. 

​Minimized errors and rework through digital workflows and real-time status tracking. 

​Improved aircraft readiness by enabling wireless part delivery and faster provisioning. 

​Lower IT and logistics costs by centralizing part management and reducing physical handling. 

​Reuse of archived parts reduces waste and procurement costs. 

​These benefits contribute to faster turnaround times, improved compliance, and enhanced operational efficiency for TechOps Avionics Engineering.
column42:
​​ Fleet Link Parts provides the following capabilities: 

​1. Import and Validation Workflow: 

​   a. Upload parts in zip files. 

​   b. Validate metadata and signatures. 

​   c. Assign statuses: Invalid, Needs Preparation, Needs Signature, Ready to Accept. 

2. ​Digital Signing and Certificate Management: 

    a. ​Manage part and crate signing certificates. 

​    b. Configure trust chains for signature validation. 

​3. Library Management: 

​   a. Store validated parts ready for export. 

​   b. Filter, sort, and view detailed part data. 

​   c. Archive or delete parts as needed. 

4. ​Export Functionality: 

​   a. Export parts as airplane or courtesy load crates. 

​   b. Sign crates digitally and manage expiration dates. 

​5. Task Management:
​  
   a. Create uplink tasks to send or remove parts from aircraft. 

​   b. Resend failed tasks and track task status.​

AI enabled purchase optimization: The Sky Select process is focused on purchase optimization.   There are 2 primary optimization paths.  ​

Purchase optimization: We will pass a requestion for purchase (part, quantity and desired lead time) Sky Select will search the market to understand all available supply.  The optimization will balance product cost, lead time and location, then estimate the total cost of the purchase.  We can configure for PO review or release based upon our business rules.​

Market Intelligence: Sky Select will analyze prices and availability-based trend data gathered from our purchases as well other airlines use of the program.  Sky Select then gives analysis on our pricing compared to the market and alerts parts availability/increasing lead times.​

Service Recovery: Sky Select optimizes sourcing process allowing a one stop shop for all available inventory, lead time and location.​

column9: “Configurable IntelliLog Assistant” is an AI-driven tool that automates log ingestion, analysis, and reporting to accelerate incident resolution. Upon a PagerDuty alert, it fetches relevant logs via Sumo Logic’s API, preprocesses them (e.g., JSON parsing), and uses an LLM to detect anomalies and generate targeted Sumo Logic queries for deeper drill-downs. The LLM then produces a concise diagnostic report—highlighting probable root causes, key metrics, and remediation steps—and delivers it back to on-call developers through PagerDuty.
column25: POC will be conducted in the GenAI dev demo account
column40:
Describe any business drivers, and technical reasons for the request...
Production incidents today require manual log searches across fragmented dashboards, leading to high MTTR and SLA breaches. Business drivers include minimizing downtime costs and support labor overhead. Technically, distributed microservices generate vast, heterogeneous logs that outstrip rule-based alerting; an LLM-powered assistant automates parsing, anomaly detection, and query synthesis to swiftly surface root-cause insights.
column41: By automating log triage and reducing MTTR by an estimated 30%, while faster incident recovery avoids penalty charges and boosts customer satisfaction, delivering a clear ROI within the first year of operation.
column42:
Alert-Driven Ingestion: Auto-trigger via PagerDuty webhooks
LLM-Based Parsing & Anomaly Detection: Converts raw logs into structured insights
Dynamic Query Generation: Crafts targeted Sumo Logic searches for deep dives
Automated Reporting: Generates concise Markdown/HTML/PDF summaries with remediation steps
Configuration UI: Lets users define sources, prompts, time windows, and thresholds
column43: All components run within AWS us-east-1: logs are fetched from Sumo Logic, and reports stored in encrypted S3. No data leaves the designated region, ensuring compliance with corporate and regulatory requirements.
column44: Delta already uses Sumo Logic for centralized log management. Its Insights feature delivers rapid anomaly detection without extra tools, but it doesn’t provide deep contextual analysis and requires professional query expertise—making root-cause investigations inconvenient and inefficient for QA engineers, developers, and managers.
column45: Teams would continue manual Sumo Logic dashboard searches and custom scripts, incurring longer MTTR, higher labor costs, and greater risk of missing subtle anomalies. They might adopt basic ML rules in existing platforms, but with limited context and no natural-language diagnostics.
column46:
Development & Integration: engineers, LLM API work
Connector Services:  PagerDuty, Sumo Logic adapters

column52:

Requires ML-ops skills, prompt engineering expertise, and Sumo Logic familiarity
column58: False positives; mitigate with continuous prompt validation, automated test suites.
column61: Pilot with one or two developers over 1 month
column64: Code and configs in GitLab and AWS Services.
column65:
Architectural Analysis:
The IntelliLog Assistant represents a forward-thinking approach to log management by leveraging AI to automate log ingestion, parsing, and analysis. Its Spring Boot foundation ensures a robust and scalable backend, while the configurable nature of the tool suggests a modular design that can adapt to various log formats and sources. However, bypassing established platforms like Sumo Logic or CloudWatch introduces challenges around scalability, security, and observability. Without native integrations, the system must handle ingestion pipelines, storage, indexing, and alerting internally, which can increase operational complexity. Additionally, the AI-driven components require careful tuning and monitoring to ensure accuracy and avoid false positives or missed anomalies.

Recommendation:
To accelerate development and validate the IntelliLog Assistant’s AI-driven capabilities, it is recommended to grant the application team controlled access to an AWS AI/ML account for a limited-scope proof of concept (POC). This will enable the team to experiment with services such as Amazon Bedrock, SageMaker, or Comprehend for log classification, anomaly detection, and natural language summarization. Leveraging AWS-managed AI services can significantly reduce the time and complexity of building custom models from scratch, while also ensuring scalability and security. The POC should be time-boxed and governed by clear usage policies, with cost monitoring and IAM role-based access controls in place to ensure responsible experimentation.

column1: Model Context Protocol (MCP) library with AWS
column9: The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open protocol that enables seamless integration between LLM applications and external data sources and tools. An MCP Server is a lightweight program that exposes specific capabilities through the standardized MCP and use this protocol to provide AI applications access to AWS documentation, contextual guidance, and best practices. Through the standardized MCP client-server architecture, AWS capabilities become an intelligent extension of your development environment or AI application.

column9: The IntuitiveMotion.AI solution is designed to address critical labor, safety, and quality challenges in Delta’s high-volume airline catering operations. This product introduces a modular, intelligent robotic system capable of automating repetitive and injury-prone tasks, such as dish handling and drink tray assembly, without requiring changes to existing workflows.
column40:
​​ The IntuitiveMotion.AI solution is designed to address critical labor, safety, and quality challenges in Delta’s high-volume airline catering operations. This product introduces a modular, intelligent robotic system capable of automating repetitive and injury-prone tasks—such as dish handling and drink tray assembly—without requiring changes to existing workflows. 

​Business Drivers: 
​Labor Shortages & Retention: Industrial kitchens face chronic staffing challenges, particularly for high-turnover, low-desirability roles like dishwashing. Our automation reduces this dependency and stabilizes operational throughput. 

​Worker Safety: Our system minimizes exposure to burns, repetitive strain injuries, and other OSHA-reportable risks, directly reducing worker compensation claims and insurance premiums. 
​Operational Consistency: Automation ensures uniform handling and quality compliance, critical for food safety, customer experience, and brand protection. 

​Technical Rationale: 
1. ​Our robots deploy and require no custom infrastructure, and integrate seamlessly via real-time edge processing. 
​2. The system uses a secured WebRTC-based teleoperation and monitoring stack, compliant with enterprise network policies and encrypted end-to-end. 
3. ​It generates high-fidelity operational and vision data to improve forecasting, compliance, and future AI learning—supporting Delta’s long-term digital transformation goals.
column41: Loading/unloading robot station each replaces tasks of 1 worker. There are 2.5 shifts per day. Each robot is $30-50k per year.
column42:
The IntuitiveMotion.AI system enables several transformative business capabilities for Delta’s kitchen and flight operations: 

1. Real-Time Operations Visibility: Operations managers can monitor dish throughput, task completion rates, and labor efficiency live—helping identify delays, bottlenecks, or underutilization. 
2. Loss Detection ("Bleeding") Alerts: The system can detect when dishware fails to return in time from aircrafts, prompting an early alert. This reduces the need for emergency dishwashing of new inventory and ensures smoother flight prep cycles. 
3. Compliance, Quality, and Safety Assurance: Embedded vision systems continuously check for chipped dishware, food debris, and proper utensil setup—helping prevent service disruptions and food safety issues. This proactive QA layer supports regulatory compliance and protects Delta’s premium in-flight service reputation. 
4. Data-Driven Optimization: Every robot interaction and camera observation contributes to a growing dataset used to optimize resource planning, staff allocation, and training—all accessible through a dashboard. 

These capabilities drive tangible improvements in operational resilience, safety, and customer experience consistency across catering hubs.
column43: ​​Currently camera image data is the only data captured externally. They are processed locally and removed each time robot reboots (every 1-6 hours).
column44:
​While several automation technologies exist, most fail to meet the adaptability, deployment speed, and compliance monitoring needs of high-volume airline catering operations. Below are potential comparisons: 

​Comparable Products: 

​Chef Robotics 

​Focus: Robotic arms for food assembly. 

​Limitations: Requires structured conveyor layouts, limited adaptability to unstructured tasks like dish handling or tray loading. 

​Miso Robotics (Flippy, Sippy) 

​Focus: Robotic burger and fry stations. 

​Limitations: Designed for QSR; not optimized for high-throughput dish operations or catering logistics. 

​Humanoid Robots (Tesla Optimus, Apptronik) 

​Focus: General-purpose manipulation. 

​Limitations: High cost, complex integration, slow to deploy, and operationally fragile in fast-paced kitchen environments. 

​Internal Delta Solutions (if any): 

​We are not aware of any existing Delta-approved solutions that combine robotics, real-time vision QA, and teleoperation tailored to dishware and catering compliance workflows.

column85: AI1 All AI environments must be fully compliant with our Information Security Policies, Standards, and Amber/ Emerald Mandates. All implementations must follow the Path to Production process. "Baseline controls: The im-delta-prod AWS account is continuously monitored by AWS Config, Security Hub, Inspector against CIS 1.4 and ISO 27001 controls (all critical findings remediated within SLA). Path-to-Production: Intuitive Motion will follow Delta’s P2P gate sequence (Dev → Stage → Prod) and will not promote to Prod until AMU shows 0 high findings and Security signs off." AI2 All AI platforms (e.g. AWS Bedrock) must use the AI-specific controls, such as Bedrock Guardrails. Phase I = edge-only inference (no cloud AI). AI3 Apply secure by design principles and Zero Trust frameworks to the architecture to manage risks to and from the AI system Outbound-only mTLS from edge → IoT Core; all cloud calls use least-privilege IAM (verified Aug-25). AI4 Ensure that the AI system and its use is within our risk tolerance. When considering whether to use other AI capabilities carefully weigh the risks and benefits, and ensure there is a human-in-the-loop where needed Initial human review of every inference; risk re-assessed quarterly before expanding to remote monitoring. AI5 Maintain a threat model for the AI system as a guide to implement security controls, assess potential threats, and plan mitigation activities No Action Required. This threat model is centrally managed. AI6 Include security requirements and standard AI contractual language in all contracts for products or services Master Service Agreement signed. AI7 Classify and protect AI models as "Restricted" data. Apply the highest levels of security - as specified in our policies and standards - to AI models Models stay on encrypted edge storage; any cloud copy will inherit “Restricted” label & KMS encryption. AI8 Identify and protect all proprietary data used to train and fine-tune AI models Ingest bucket is private; separate analytics role (no write). Quarterly access review. AI9 Ensure there is logging and visibility into AI model usage to quickly detect AI-based threats CloudTrail + IoT logs sent to Splunk; detection rule “AI-Threat-01” enabled. AI10 Use cryptographic methods, digital signatures, and checksums to confirm the origin and integrity of custom-developed or fine-tuned AI models Placeholder—full when OTA model updates start Phase II. Implementation plan: SHA-256 in IoT Job doc + SigV4-signed S3 URL; Jetson verifies hash before symlink swap. AI11 Create hashes and encrypted copies of each release of the custom-developed and fine-tuned AI models, and a system for archival in a tamper-proof location Not applicable for ths evaluation phase. AI12 Store all forms of code (e.g., source code, executable code, infrastructure as code) and model artifacts (e.g., models, parameters, configurations, data, tests) in a version control system with proper access controls https://github.com/IntuitiveMotion Code & artefacts in private Git service with SSO + 2-review branch protection (audit log retained 1 yr). AI13 Periodically test AI models for robustness, accuracy, and potential vulnerabilities. Apply techniques such as penetration testing to evaluate the model's resilience against compromise attempts. When updating the model to a new/different version, run a full evaluation to ensure that accuracy, performance, and security tests are within acceptable limits before redeploying Not applicable for ths evaluation phase. AI14 Prepare for automated deployments and rollbacks, with human-in-the-loop for continuous delivery approval (e.g. merge requests) for AI systems Not applicable for ths evaluation phase. AI15 Evaluate and secure the supply chain for any external AI models and data, making sure they adhere to organizational standards and risk management policies Not applicable. No external AI models. AI16 Do not run models in the enterprise environment until the models, especially imported pre-trained models, are inspected and tested inside a secure development zone " All new models validated in isolated lab account before field rollout." AI17 Implement validation and sanitization protocols for all input data to reduce the risk of undesired, suspicious, incompatible, or malicious input being passed to the AI system Data pipeline enforces schema. We do not collect human related data. AI18 Monitor the system's behavior, inputs, and outputs for attempts to access or elicit data from the AI model or aggregate inference responses, to detect any abnormal behavior or potential security incidents, for data drift, and for high frequency or repetitive inputs We will start with human oversight onsite, and once established, we will ease into remote monitoring for multiple robots/vision check systems. AI19 Notify administrators and App Owners of potential adversarial compromise attempts, security breaches, or anomalies to respond accordingly We will use CloudWatch for any alerts needed for overseeing S3 storage AI20 Ensure APIs return only the minimal data required for the task to inhibit model inversion No APIs run in cloud AI21 Engage security experts to conduct audits and penetration testing on ready-to-deploy AI systems Not applicable for this evaluation phase AI22 Prepare for high availability (HA) and disaster recovery (DR), and use appropriate backup storage system, depending on the requirements of the system Edge buffers 24 h; cloud storage cross-region replicated.

Pytest is a powerful open-source testing framework for Python, widely used for unit, functional, and API testing. It enables developers and QA engineers to write simple as well as scalable test cases with minimal boilerplate code. 

Key aspects of Pytest include: 

Python Testing: Designed specifically for testing Python applications, including APIs, backend logic, and data processing. 

Simple Syntax: Allows writing tests using plain functions and assert statements, making tests easy to read and maintain. 

Extensibility: Supports plugins and fixtures for modular, reusable, and scalable test setups.

column9:
***This STR is to move PilotPBS application from Delta owned Hardware hosted by NAVBLUE  to NAVBLUE 's SaaS Cloud infrastructure.***

Pilot preferential bidding system. Used by pilots to enter scheduling preferences and award pilot schedules. Currently used to identify Delta owned hardware and network components that support the NAVBLUE vendor (Toronto and Calgary).  
Pilot PBS has the following business functions:
- Allows pilots to submit preferences regarding their flight schedule each month. These preferences can be entered from any device with internet access. Some examples of pilot bid preferences are: like weekends off, productivity flights, avoid layovers in a certain stations, etc.
- Allows designated Flight Operations personnel (i.e. PBS Administrators) to configure parameters/constraints to ensure that the schedules created meet DL
- The pilot work rules and FAA regulations are built into the system. Examples of DL work rules include open time allowed by category, boundaries for min and max schedules, etc.
-Enables planners to build monthly pilot flight schedules that meet the business constraints and takes into consideration the pilot preferences.
column25:
9/22/25: STR approved
Pending items: PIA, contract execution, check status of VRA
This application is currently used by Pilots in PROD.  STR is to move from Delta owned hardware hosted by NAVBLUE to NAVBLUE 's SaaS cloud infrastructure.
column40: Current production environment is hosted at Navblue data center using the hardware purchased by Delta. New environment will run on Navblue's cloud infrastructure.  Navblue is currently migrating all their customers to their cloud-based SaaS infrastructure.  Current application runs on old hardware and unsupported RHEL platform which is not compatible with latest version of the application and also integration with Delta SSO/MFA is not possible with current platform.  Moving to new SaaS infrastructure uses latest RHEL and future upgrades and patching are better managed.  This helps us move to latest version of the app with SSO/MFA integration as well as any application fixes and enhancements will only be done in new platform.

column9:
Figma’s Dev Mode MCP (Model Context Protocol) server is a new beta feature designed to integrate Figma directly into developer workflows by providing rich design context to AI coding tools. Traditionally, AI tools relied on static images or API responses to interpret design intent, but the MCP server changes this by offering a standardized way to deliver structured design data to large language models (LLMs). This enables tools like GitHub Copilot, Amazon Q Developer, and AWS Kiro to generate code that aligns more closely with the actual design and existing codebase. The server supports features like extracting variables, components, and layout data, and it can generate code from selected frames in Figma using popular UI frameworks like React, Tailwind, and SwiftUI. It also includes Code Connect, which maps Figma components directly to their codebase counterparts, ensuring consistency and reducing guesswork in code generation.

This MCP server is SaaS-based and there is no additional cost. The authorization and authentication for the remote MCP server follows existing access entitlements within Figma and utilizes their browser user-agent and authorize the MCP client with a specific MCP OAuth scope.
column25:
9/2/25: MCP STRs are on hold until the proper controls are in place
8/21/25: STR approved
Pending items: add AI language to either MSA or Eval Agreement
The VRA is due June 2029
column40: As a frontend development team working extensively with Figma and actively growing our design system, UI kit, and component library, we see a clear need for the Dev Mode MCP server. It gives our developers and AI coding tools direct access to structured design data, which helps eliminate the guesswork that comes with interpreting static visuals. With this integration, we can generate code that’s tightly aligned with our actual design components, variables, and layout logic. It also supports component mapping through Code Connect, which helps us maintain consistency across our codebase and design system. This kind of precision and efficiency is essential as we scale and evolve our design infrastructure.
column41: Adopting Figma’s Dev Mode MCP server delivers clear business value by accelerating development workflows and improving design-to-code fidelity. By enabling AI tools to access structured design data directly from Figma, teams can generate production-ready code that aligns with established design systems and component libraries, reducing manual translation and rework. This leads to faster feature delivery, improved collaboration between design and engineering, and greater consistency across digital products. Ultimately, it helps organizations scale their frontend development efforts more efficiently while maintaining high-quality user interfaces.
column42:
Generate Code from Selected Frames: Turn selected Figma frames into code using AI tools, with default output in React + Tailwind, and support for other frameworks like SwiftUI and HTML/CSS.

Extract Design Context: Pull variables, components, and layout data directly into your IDE to support design systems and component-based workflows.

Code Connect Integration: Map Figma components to their corresponding codebase implementations, ensuring consistent reuse and reducing guesswork.

get_code Tool: Produces structured code output based on your Figma selection, customizable by framework, styling system, and file path.

get_variable_defs Tool: Returns design tokens used in a selection, including color, spacing, typography, and their values.

get_code_connect_map Tool: Provides mappings between Figma node IDs and code components, including file paths and component names.

get_image Tool: Captures screenshots of selected frames to preserve layout fidelity and supplement design context.

Selection-Based and Link-Based Prompting: Allows developers to prompt AI tools using either selected elements in Figma or shared links to specific frames or layers.

Local Server via SSE Protocol: Runs locally through the Figma desktop app and communicates with supported IDEs like VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf, and Claude Code.

Customizable Server Settings: Toggle features like image extraction, placeholder usage, and Code Connect mappings to optimize output and token usage.

Supports Agentic Coding Tools: Designed to work with AI assistants that use contextual data to generate code aligned with your design and codebase.

Improves Design-to-Code Fidelity: Helps LLMs understand design intent beyond visuals, including structure, interactivity, and metadata.
column43: N/A
column45: If this initiative were not adopted, our team would likely continue relying on manual processes and static design exports to bridge the gap between design and development. This would mean interpreting visuals without structured context, increasing the risk of inconsistencies between design intent and implementation. AI coding tools would remain limited in their ability to generate accurate, component-aligned code, leading to more rework and slower development cycles. We’d also miss out on the opportunity to streamline collaboration between designers and developers, and to scale our design system with the precision and efficiency that the MCP server enables.

column65: Approved
column85: Information Security: Operates within Delta’s corporate network via Amazon Q CLI or Amazon Kiro, ensuring compliance with InfoSec policies, standards, and Amber/Emerald mandates. No sensitive data is transmitted externally without encryption or user control. Path to Production: The MCP server is used in a software development context and does not directly deploy code. Any generated code follows Delta’s standard Path to Production processes, including peer review, CI/CD pipelines, and testing. AI Controls: AI-generated code is produced through integrations with third-party tools (e.g., AWS Q Developer) using explainable logic based on structured design data. Developers retain full control over code acceptance and modification. Secure Architecture: The MCP server communicates via secure protocols (HTTPS), adhering to Zero Trust principles and secure-by-design architecture. It does not expose internal systems or data to external threats. Risk Alignment: AI usage is limited to augmenting frontend development with human-in-the-loop oversight. All outputs are reviewed and validated by developers before integration, aligning with Delta’s risk tolerance. Threat Modeling: The MCP server operates within the Figma environment and is covered under Figma’s centralized security and threat model, which includes regular updates and vulnerability management. Restricted Data Protection: No restricted or classified data is used in training or is transmitted via the MCP server. All design context remains within the bounds of Figma’s secure infrastructure and Delta’s network. Monitoring & Logging: While the MCP server itself does not log AI decisions, IDEs and development environments can be configured to track usage, outputs, and anomalies. Logging can be integrated into existing observability tools. Version Control & Testing: Generated code is versioned and tested within standard development workflows. The MCP server supports reproducible outputs based on design selections, enabling consistent testing and validation. Auditability: All AI-generated code is traceable to specific design inputs and developer prompts. This ensures transparency and supports audit requirements for design-to-code translation.

column9: Zero Networks is a cybersecurity company that segments every asset by automatically learning network connections and creating accurate security policies. These policies create firewall bubbles around all of your assets, with privileged ports closed and layered with MFA coverage – by default. Block lateral movement, end ransomware.

column40: Micro segmentation between client and servers, reduces lateral movement to prevent bad actor to access our resources.  Zero Network product give us a flexibility to perform micro-segmentation without changing the IP network.
column41: A leased privileged access model with just intime user access can be deployed to provide immediate security without major infrastructure change.
column42: ​​ Zero Networks is a revolutionary network attack prevention solution that automatically learns how your devices normally communicate and ensures network access is available only when needed – blocking all other connections, including malicious attempts to enumerate and traverse your network. By giving network access only to the devices that need it and only when they need it, Zero Networks prevents network discovery and lateral movement. ​
column43: In Zero networks Cloud (Private GCP cloud).  They are hosting their SaaS service in their private cloud hosted in GCP. They followed compliant policy and are SOC2 compliant.
column46: This is an Opex based solution. We will be paying for license to segment either client or server machines ( Windows , Mac or Linux)  . We bought 15000 server licenses. This is a SaaS service.
column51: ​​Day 1 support, will follow the Network Security Engineering support process​
column61:
-- Deploy Delta tenant on their SaaS portal.
-- Enable PingIDP for authentication using MFA to access the portal.
-- Only Network Security engineering team can have read and write access , if they are coming from Delta network. 
-- Integrate with ServiceNow to  get list of all the application servers based on Block code or Syscode.
-- Deploy segment server in our on-prem environment. Ensure it has line of sigh to all our endpoints. 
-- Ensure Segment server can communicate to Zero Network portal ( Delta Tenant) using secure 443. 
-- Once segment server has access to all our assets through Active Directory for windows assets using WinRM. For Linux endpoints, it uses iptables logs to either rsyslog or ulog2 and ssh is used together network data for analysis in policy engine in SaaS. 
           - For windows assets or Mac users  that are not in the line of sight of segment server, a client will be deployed. 
-- Once Segment server is deployed, it will be 90 days learning period for policy engine to create the polices for endpoints. 
-- Review the policies with app owners before enable segmentation (enforcement).

column40:
The OCC team manages aeronautical data from numerous countries, which is often costly, fragmented, and difficult to track. Avinym simplifies this by offering a centralized, browser-based platform that includes a global AIP library and automated alerts for updates and revisions.

This tool enhances operational efficiency by ensuring timely access to critical information without requiring data integration or sharing. Its ease of use and relevance to navigation and planning make it a strong candidate for adoption following a trial evaluation.
column41: Avinym streamlines access to global Aeronautical Information Publications (AIPs), reducing manual effort, improving update visibility, and enhancing operational accuracy for flight planning and navigation.
column42: It provides a centralized AIP library, automated alerts for country-specific updates and revisions, and a browser-based interface for quick access and reference.
column43: Avinym is a browser-based solution with no data integration or sharing. All data remains external, and no Delta data is stored or processed within the tool.
column44: There are no known approved tools at Delta that offer the same centralized AIP access and update alerting. Current processes rely on manual procurement and monitoring from individual country sources.
column45: The team would continue manually sourcing AIPs from multiple providers, increasing workload, risk of missed updates, and operational inefficiencies.
column46: There are no one-time costs associated with implementation. Avinym is currently being evaluated through a free trial, with no integration or infrastructure changes required.
column47: None required. The solution is cloud-hosted and accessed via standard web browsers.
column48: Negligible. No dedicated IT support is needed. OCC users will manage access and usage directly.
column49: No formal operational support from Delta IT is expected. Vendor support would be leveraged for any product-related issues.
column50: Not applicable. Avinym is hosted externally and does not utilize Delta’s AWS environment.
column51: Avinym requires minimal ongoing support. As a browser-based tool with no integration into Delta systems, day-to-day usage will be managed by OCC business users. Any product-related issues or enhancements will be handled directly through vendor support channels. No dedicated Delta IT resources are expected for operational maintenance.
column52: Minimal support required. OCC users will manage day-to-day usage, with vendor-provided support available for product-related issues. No dedicated Delta IT support is expected.
column53: No new skills or tooling are required. Ownership will reside within the OCC team, with existing staff able to use the tool without additional training or technical onboarding.
column54: Avinym may reduce reliance on manual AIP sourcing and tracking processes, potentially retiring fragmented workflows and subscriptions to individual country publications.
column58: Operational risk is low due to Avinym’s non-integrated, browser-based nature. The primary risk is reliance on vendor uptime and accuracy of AIP updates. This is mitigated by maintaining access to existing AIP sources during the trial and validating Avinym’s alerts against known updates before full adoption.
column61: Begin with a limited trial within the OCC team to validate functionality and fit. Feedback from users will guide next steps toward broader adoption.
column62: If the trial proves successful, the tool will be rolled out to relevant OCC teams involved in navigation and flight planning. Licensing and vendor engagement will be formalized post-trial.
column63: Use is limited to OCC operational teams. The tool is not integrated with Delta systems and is intended solely for reference and monitoring of AIP updates.
column64: No internal repository required. The product is accessed via the vendor’s site: https://avinym.com
column65: Avinym presents a low-risk, high-value opportunity for OCC operations. Its browser-based architecture eliminates the need for integration, infrastructure changes, or data residency concerns. The tool aligns well with OCC’s business needs by centralizing AIP access and automating update notifications. Given its minimal IT footprint, ease of use, and operational relevance, it is recommended to proceed with the trial and evaluate for broader adoption based on user feedback and vendor performance.

Life at Work is the Conduent product that provides the employees:
- Benefit Election information,

-this is also integrated with a chat engagement option that allows employees to engage with the Employee Service Center, the 800 My Delta Service Center (MDSC), The chat feature is provided by a Conduent agreement with LivePerson.

This STR is to activate the AI capabilities of LivePerson Chat in the Life At Work product. The initial validation period established connectivity to Delta’s Service Now solution with a selection of 30 KB articles authorized for the LivePerson generative AI to use as part of a previously approved POC. The 30 initial knowledge base articles in the POC was leveraged to respond to questions in the Life @ Work portal with the current chat bot feature for Delta employees.  The initial POC was deemed successful with 30 articles and they expanded to 70 KB articles to gather more feedback and have subsequently decided to move forward with full approval.

Moving forward they intend to expand the scope of KB articles for this solution initially to 168 KB articles and is expected to provide better consistency between knowledge articles and chat responses including the MDSC staff responses as they have access to the AI tool recommended answers.

column9: Pluralytics is an AI-powered platform that provides content intelligence, allowing brands to optimize their messaging based on the underlying values of their target audiences.
column25:

Pending items: PIA, VRA, contract
VRA Engagement: 37482817
column40:
Pluralytics offers a strategic advantage for enhancing communication effectiveness across the organization. Key reasons for its use include:

•	Smarter Word Choices - Pluralytics helps brands choose language that better connects with their audience by showing which words and phrases are more engaging.

•	Consistent Messaging Across Channels - Whether it's a website, email, social media post, or ad campaign, Pluralytics supports consistent tone and branding across all communications.

•	Better Audience Understanding - The platform reveals how different messages make people feel and what values they respond to, helping teams tailor content more effectively.

•	Science-Backed Messaging - Pluralytics combines research and behavioral insights to help brands improve how they communicate and build stronger relationships with their audiences.
column41:
Business Benefit:

•	Boosts Productivity - Pluralytics helps communicators get started faster by generating draft messaging tailored to the audience and communication channel.

•	Improves Engagement - Global Communications can improve message effectiveness by using insights that align content with audience values and preferences, leading to more meaningful connections.
column42:
Pluralytics offers the following capabilities:

•	Accelerates Content Creation - Generates draft messaging tailored to specific audiences and communication channels, helping communicators begin more efficiently.

•	Enhances Communication Effectiveness -Recommends language that resonates with audiences while avoiding potentially divisive terms—supporting clearer, more inclusive messaging across the organization.

•	Improves Message Impact - Enables Global Communications and divisional teams to craft messaging that better aligns with audience values, leading to stronger engagement.

•	Supports Brand Voice Consistency - Maintains a unified tone across platforms and departments, reinforcing brand identity.

•	Informs Messaging Decisions - Provides insights that guide more thoughtful and strategic communication choices.

column9: Cision AI Powered Media Monitoring (Brandwatch) is an advanced media intelligence tool that leverages artificial intelligence to help organizations track and analyze media coverage, manage public relations campaigns, and gain real-time insights into brand discussions across various channel
column25:
Cision - Brandwatch Consumer Research (non- AI) is currently in production and was not properly vetted through the IT process. It has been in production for 5+ years.

In addition to Global Communications users, select employees from Edelman, an external partner, also have access to Delta’s Brandwatch instance.

Edelman is a key partner in monitoring issues for Delta. They use Brandwatch to pull together quarterly trend reports and manage the queries behind our issue alerts. These alerts are powered by searches that run continuously to catch sudden spikes in hot topics—like Delta being mentioned in geopolitical conversations—or an overall rise in negative sentiment. Edelman’s support is essential because they bring the expertise and tools to track these trends accurately and help us respond quickly before issues escalate.
column40: Cision AI Powered Media Monitoring offers businesses comprehensive insights, real-time updates, and the ability to manage brand reputation effectively, making it an essential tool for modern PR strategies.
column41:
Key Benefits of Cision Media Monitoring

• Comprehensive Coverage - Tracks media mentions across print, broadcast, online, and social platforms globally, ensuring no critical coverage is missed.

• AI-Powered Insights - Leverages artificial intelligence to identify trends, sentiment, and emerging narratives, helping teams make data-driven decisions.

• Real-Time Alerts - Provides instant notifications for relevant media activity, enabling timely responses to both opportunities and risks.

• In-Depth Analytics - Offers detailed metrics on reach, engagement, sentiment, and share of voice to evaluate campaign performance and media impact.

• Competitive Analysis - Monitors competitors’ media presence and public perception, offering strategic insights to stay ahead in the market.

• Streamlined Workflow - Integrates existing tools and automates reporting, saving time and improving team efficiency.

• Social Listening Capabilities - Captures conversations and trends across social media platforms to understand audience behavior and brand reputation.

column1: EPI-USE Labs PRISM for SAP S/4 HANA
column9:
Delta SAP HRIS comprises of SAP Payroll which processes payroll for 100K+ employees. Delta is evaluating migrating SAP HCM system currently runs on SAP ERP 6.0, Enhancement Pack 8. SAP will stop supporting this version by end of December 31, 2027. Extended maintenance for these versions is until December 31, 2030, at an additional cost. After these dates, SAP will no longer provide standard support, including security updates and legal changes, unless customers purchase extended maintenance. 

SAP HR is evaluating different migration paths, one of which is to migrate SAP Employee Central (EC) Payroll. EPI-USE Labs PRISM is a migration service that provides assessment and evaluations tools to efficiently migrate on-premise payroll. This tool will evaluate current SAP HR payroll configuration and suggest efficient migration path to S/4 HANA or SAP Employee Central Payroll. 

EPI-USE is current Delta vendor whose add-on tools query manager and data synch manager are currently installed on SAP HCM on-premise system.
column25:
9/23/25: STR approved

column40:
Delta SAP HRIS comprises of SAP Payroll which processes payroll for 100K+ employees. Delta is evaluating migrating SAP HCM system currently runs on SAP ERP 6.0, Enhancement Pack 8. SAP will stop supporting this version by end of December 31, 2027. Extended maintenance for these versions is until December 31, 2030, at an additional cost. After these dates, SAP will no longer provide standard support, including security updates and legal changes, unless customers purchase extended maintenance. 

SAP HR is evaluating different migration paths, one of which is to migrate SAP Employee Central (EC) Payroll. EPI-USE Labs PRISM is a migration service that provides assessment and evaluations tools to efficiently migrate on-premise payroll. This tool will evaluate current SAP HR payroll configuration and suggest efficient migration path to S/4 HANA or SAP Employee Central Payroll. 

The end product of the assessment is an output file that provides details of Payroll Configuration. No Employee Data is include in the output file.
column41: Speeds up migration of SAP on-premise payroll system to cloud. Provides an efficient path to SAP Employee Central Payroll
column42: Does not offer new business capabilities. It is migration assessment tool that provides a file based output for evaluating current Delta Payroll Configuration. It effectively assesses our SAP HR payroll system without extracting any sensitive business or employee information. Employees PII information is protected. Delta business information like payroll configuration is also protected. Delta can download and review the XML file before transmitting to EPI-USE Labs for analysis.
column65: Approved to engage EPI-USE Labs PRISM migration assessment service to evaluate Delta’s current SAP HCM Payroll configuration and recommend an efficient migration path to SAP S/4HANA or SAP Employee Central Payroll. This initiative addresses SAP ERP 6.0 support ending in 2027 (with extended maintenance until 2030 at additional cost) and ensures compliance with future SAP roadmap requirements. EPI-USE is an existing Delta vendor with proven tools (Query Manager, Data Sync Manager) already in use on our SAP HCM system.

column9: Obstore is a Python interface to Amazon S3, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Storage, & other S3-compliant APIs, powered by Rust.
column40:
Obstore library provides below benefits from a development perspective when accessing data from an S3 bucket.
- One interface for all backends with no required Python dependencies.
- Sync and async API with full type hinting.
- Streaming downloads with configurable chunking.
- Streaming uploads from files or async or sync iterators.
- Streaming list, with no need to paginate.
- Automatic multipart uploads for large file objects.
- Automatic credential refresh before expiration.
- File-like object API and fsspec integration.
- Optionally return list results in Apache Arrow format, which is faster and more memory-efficient than materializing Python dicts.
- Zero-copy data exchange between Rust and Python via the buffer protocol.

column40:
Figma AI is essential for empowering design teams to work smarter, faster, and more collaboratively. Design work often involves repetitive, time-consuming tasks such as formatting, layout adjustments, copy generation, image manipulation, and component alignment. These manual activities can slow down productivity and divert focus from creative problem-solving.
Figma AI addresses these challenges by introducing intelligent features that automate and accelerate routine design workflows. It enhances collaboration by enabling real-time suggestions, rapid prototyping, and content generation directly within the design platform. This allows designers to iterate faster, reduce manual effort, and maintain creative momentum.
By streamlining tedious tasks and supporting intuitive, AI-powered design assistance, Figma AI frees up valuable time for design teams to focus on innovation and higher-value work—ultimately improving efficiency, quality, and time-to-market for digital products.
column41:
Figma AI helps design teams save time by automating repetitive tasks, improving collaboration, and accelerating the design process. This leads to faster time-to-market, better resource utilization, and higher-quality outputs.
ROI: By saving hours weekly per designer and reducing the need for rework or additional headcount, Figma AI delivers strong cost savings and efficiency—providing a clear return on investment.

column9:
eDiscovery is the process of identifying, collecting, and producing electronically stored information (ESI) for legal or regulatory purposes. It’s commonly used during litigation, investigations, or audits to gather relevant digital data such as emails, documents, chats, and files.

The vendor Lineal, will be providing the same services as KLDiscovery, the current eDiscovery provider does, but are using Lineal for their expertise, specifically in the CrowdStrike Litigation.  This is a review tool used by legal teams for reviewing and production of documents in active litigation. Only attorneys would have access to the data in the tool.   

Lineal is providing eDiscovery and forensics services for litigation matters. They have specific expertise and tools that are needed (and that our other eDiscovery providers do not have), and that is why we need to onboard them. They offer Relativity – which is a standard in the eDiscovery world – with their own add-ons which make it different than going directly to Relativity. It is used to process, review and produce data that is relevant to the litigation. This process is required for all of our litigations, and certain matters require certain expertise (i.e. an IP litigation is different from a Second Request is different from an Antitrust action.). As such, we cannot use just one vendor for all of our needs. 
Only attorneys have access to the database as all work product and data collections are protected by the attorney-client privilege. 
Any AI being used also falls under attorney-client privilege. We are not generating NEW data, the analytics and AI functions are only used to categorize/review our documents so that we can produce the relevant/not privileged docs. 
The vendor services being provided are a combination of SaaS and Professional Services.  The technology that the Delta eDiscovery team will be using is not a separate subscription/installation.  Lineal provides that at no cost within their cloud-based platform since Delta is utilizing their SaaS data hosting model and other professional services.
column25:
eDiscovery collection transmission:
- SFTP - Standard transmission of eDiscovery collections is by SFTP: Lineal has the capability to receive electronic files directly from clients using a secure mode of electronic transmission. We use the Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) that requires SSH to be enabled. All data in transit is encrypted using TLS (version 1.2), VPN, and SFTP. All data at rest uses encryption with AES 256 algorithm.  
- Encrypted hard drives - For very large eDiscovery collections, transmission is by Physical Transmission: As a standard, they transfer data using 2TB encrypted hard drives. Amanda has the additional approvals required by Delta for using encrypted hard drives for processing.

MFA access management:
Amanda (manager for the Law Department's eDiscovery team) is the only one who will be approving access to the Lineal workspaces. Only individuals specifically working on the matter (inside attorneys and outside counsel) will be provided access credentials. Also, Amanda audits the access log every month to remove access for anyone who has not logged in within the past 30 days.  SSO is not feasible because of all the outside counsel that needs access.

- When a litigation matter is completed and Delta no longer needs to preserve the collected data, the workspace is deleted along with all originally collected data. Then, internally, Amanda's team removes the legal hold from Delta systems (because we preserve the original data in-place in our own environment.) The vendor keeps none of our data. Part of the reason all this goes through Amanda's team – so they can track where Delta's data is and make sure it’s deleted when it’s no longer needed. 

- Contract terms - The SOW lists dates the rates will be applicable, and SCM/Amanda's team reconnects with the vendor when the SOW is up for renewal to determine how to proceed for the next 1-3 years.
column40: We are using Lineal for their expertise, specific in the CrowdStrike Litigation.  Lineal uses the same base offering (Relativity), but their enhancements (specifically ChatCraft and a few other analytics review tools) are needed to ensure the legal team complies with the production obligations required for litigations and government investigations. From an eDiscovery perspective, it also makes sense for us to house our bigger litigation matters in a few different locations.
column41:
The vendor services being provided are a combination of SaaS and Professional Services.  The technology that the Delta eDiscovery team will be using is not a separate subscription/installation.  Lineal provides that at no cost within their cloud-based platform since Delta is utilizing their SaaS data hosting model and other professional services
The ultimate benefit is lower legal fees. Lineal enhancements allow us to work more efficiently, thereby reducing our outside spend on document review and analysis.
column42: Lineal has specific expertise for the CrowdStrike Litigation. Their Relativity add-ons speed-up the review of documents required in litigation and government investigations. The ability to categorize, analyze and substantively code documents are the main features of their Relativity offering. The tool also prepares documents in the format required by our ESI Protocols, producing them in compliance with our legal obligations.
column43: Lineal owns and maintains all equipment in their data centers and colocation. Primary Data & Evidence Office: 5200 77 Center Drive, Charlotte, NC 28217; US Colocation: 1950 North Stemmons Freeway, Suites 1039A & 2048, Dallas, TX 75207. RelOne data is hosted in the U.S. Azure Cloud.
column44: The vendor Lineal, will be providing the same services that KLD, the current eDiscovery provider does, but are using Lineal for their expertise, specific in the CrowdStrike Litigation. Relativity is an industry-standard review platform – which we currently utilize from a handful of different providers (due to their differing offerings). KLD, PageOne and Lineal all provide these review tools and specific enhancements for different types of litigation.  Different variations of Relativity have already been approved by Delta over the past few years.
column45:
We have other Relativity providers, but due to the subject-nature of this litigation, we need the specific tools they offer to meet our legal obligations. As stated above, from a privilege, business-continuity and eDiscovery perspective, it makes sense to have a few different service providers in this area.  Again, we are not paying for services we are not using – this is just needed for the lifetime of a litigation matter (which can proceed for years).
If we don’t use the model implemented by the Delta eDiscovery team, the alternative is having each of our panel law firms choose their own eDiscovery service providers to handle our litigation matters. This means Delta has no insight into the security of those vendors, there is no guarantee they meet any of our requirements, and our proprietary data is floating around hundreds of places – most of which we cannot track/do not even know.
column46: No implementation costs. We only pay for services based on our actual level of consumption.

PagerDuty's local MCP (Model Context Protocol) server which provides tools to interact with your PagerDuty account, allowing you to manage incidents, services, schedules, and more directly from your MCP-enabled client.

The "PagerDuty MCP Server" refers to a server that acts as a bridge between Large Language Models (LLMs) and PagerDuty API,. This allows LLMs to interact with and manage various PagerDuty resources programmatically,
Using the PagerDuty MCP Server allows programmatic interaction with PagerDuty resources via structured inputs and outputs, which is beneficial for LLMs.

IT teams are rapidly adopting AI for convenience and efficiency in their day-to-day work.  We need AI to bring context and suggest precise root cause, generate tests automatically, auto-collect information to fix vulnerabilities, and recommend optimizations based on real production insights.

Enhanced incident response by allowing PagerDuty to quickly integrate information from monitoring systems.
Unified workflows by facilitating cross-platform data access and integration from other systems.

Improved AI collaboration by supporting AI assistants that manage response scenarios.
Comprehensive reporting and analytics through aggregated data from multiple sources.

column9:
The k-6 Operator is a ROSA (Kubernetes) operator that enables running k6 tests as distributed tests.

Summary from k6:
https://grafana.com/docs/k6/latest/testing-guides/running-distributed-tests/#introducing-k6-operator
Introducing k6-operator
k6-operator is an implementation of the operator pattern in Kubernetes, defining custom resources in Kubernetes. The intent is to automate tasks that a human operator would normally do; tasks like provisioning new application components, changing configurations, or resolving run-time issues.

The k6-operator defines the custom TestRun resource type and listens for changes to, or creation of, TestRun objects. Each TestRun object references a k6 test script, configures the environment, and specifies the number of instances, as parallelism, for a test run. Once a change is detected, the operator will react by modifying the cluster state, spinning up k6 test jobs as needed.

9/1/25: STR approved
Pending items: AI mandate evidence template
Getting access to a kubernetes MCP server will allow developers to debug issues regarding there kubernetes workload and also interact in a readonly mode with the cluster
column40: The Kubernetes MCP Server was created to give AI assistants a safe, structured, and native way to interact with Kubernetes and OpenShift clusters. From a business perspective, it reduces complexity for developers and operators by enabling natural language–driven operations, while also promoting community adoption through its move into the neutral Containers organization. Technically, it avoids external dependencies by being written in Go and connecting directly to the Kubernetes API instead of wrapping CLI tools. It exposes controlled, schema-defined operations like listing pods, retrieving logs, or describing resources, which makes automation more secure and predictable than granting full CLI access. Overall, the project addresses both the operational burden of Kubernetes management and the need for a community-driven, AI-ready interface to clusters.
column41: The business benefit of the Kubernetes MCP Server is that it lowers the cost and effort required to operate Kubernetes by enabling AI-driven automation and reducing manual intervention. Today, cluster troubleshooting, log retrieval, and resource inspections can take engineers hours of context switching across CLI tools, whereas with MCP these tasks can be streamlined into natural language interactions that resolve issues faster and with fewer mistakes. This leads directly to cost savings in reduced Mean Time to Resolution (MTTR) for incidents, less time spent on repetitive operations, and faster onboarding for new engineers who no longer need deep Kubernetes expertise to perform common tasks. The ROI comes from labor savings, higher platform availability, and the ability to scale operations support without scaling headcount proportionally. In short, MCP Server drives efficiency, reduces operational overhead, and improves reliability—resulting in measurable cost savings across both infrastructure operations and developer productivity.
column42:
The Kubernetes MCP Server delivers several business capabilities that directly support efficiency and scale in Kubernetes operations:

1. **AI-Assisted Operations** – Enables natural language interaction with clusters, allowing engineers and support staff to diagnose and resolve issues faster without needing deep Kubernetes expertise.
2. **Operational Efficiency** – Automates repetitive tasks like retrieving logs, checking pod status, or describing resources, reducing manual work and freeing engineers to focus on higher-value activities.
3. **Faster Incident Response** – Lowers Mean Time to Resolution (MTTR) by providing quick, structured access to cluster information through AI agents, improving service uptime and reliability.
4. **Workforce Scalability** – Reduces the learning curve for new hires, making it easier for less experienced engineers to perform Kubernetes operations safely, which helps scale teams without proportional increases in training costs.
5. **Governance and Security** – Offers a controlled, schema-defined interface to Kubernetes resources, ensuring that AI-driven automation adheres to RBAC and enterprise security policies, mitigating risk compared to exposing raw CLI access.
column43: For the Kubernetes MCP Server, data residency follows the location of the Kubernetes cluster and the MCP server instance where it is deployed. All data—such as pod logs, resource descriptions, and API responses—is retrieved directly from the Kubernetes API and processed locally within the cluster or the environment hosting the MCP server. No data is sent externally by default; processing occurs in the same infrastructure where the server is running, under the enterprise’s existing compliance and security controls. This ensures that residency aligns with the organization’s cloud or on-premises policies (e.g., AWS region, private datacenter, or hybrid environment). If integrated with an AI assistant, residency will then depend on that assistant’s deployment model (enterprise self-hosted vs. SaaS), but the MCP server itself does not persist or transmit data outside of the managed environment.

column9:
Enterprise Payments Agent – Delta Air Lines

The agent acts as a digital subject matter expert (SME) for the Enterprise Payments domain at Delta Air Lines. PowerAutomate or proprietary UI application will invoke the agent to serve the user queries.

Future scope: Other agents can communicate to this via the A2A protocol by passing the relevant context, prompt and security tokens. 

This intelligent assistant is designed to support a wide range of tasks, including:

1. Answering domain-specific queries related to Enterprise Payments operations.
2. Providing test data for validation and QA purposes in lower environment.
3. Providing pre-defined SQL queries to the user to retrieve relevant data from backend databases.
4. Offering contextual guidance for troubleshooting and analytics.

The Agent serves as a digital SME, streamlining access to complex payment-related information and accelerating decision-making across teams.

About Enterprise Payments at Delta Air Lines:

Enterprise Payments is a critical business domain that handles diverse transaction types across multiple digital and physical channels, including:

1. Delta.com and the Fly Delta app for e-commerce transactions.
2. Flight reservations and ticketing systems.
3. Card-present transactions at airport kiosks (e.g., baggage purchases).

This domain ensures secure, efficient, and scalable processing of payments, supporting Delta’s commitment to seamless customer experiences across its global operations.

Questions:
Its not clear what Agent will be consuming this MCP. Can you update the diagram and request to show what or how users will be interacting with this MCP (Custom Agent/Q CLI/Etc). If its Q CLI then how will you restrict access based on the individual user? 

The consumers can access this agent using API or user tokens via established Delta security patterns as laid out in MCP Security Overview - Delta Cloud Documentation. Centralized authorizer will be leveraged to verify the Ping ID tokens passed in the request to the agent and in the downstream calls (if any).

Also, I saw in the diagram bedrock calling the MCP or the MCP interacting with bedrock. Can you clarify why bedrock access is needed and being used within this MCP.

We have updated the terminology to ‘Agent’ from ‘MCP server’ based on the capabilities and scope of the effort. Bedrock is used here for knowledgebase, summarization and ‘LLM as judge’ pattern to verify the response before passing it to the consumer.
column25:
1. The Agent does not process or store any PII or PCI data. It is compliant with all GDPR, PSD2 and other mandatory payments compliances and mandates.
2. It is designed to be UI-agnostic, supporting integration with platforms like MS Teams, Delta proprietary applications, Amazon Q, and other LLM ecosystems.
3. The server is owned and maintained solely by the Enterprise Payments team, ensuring domain expertise and operational control.

1.	You should cleanup the references, for example, what MCP stands for...Model Context Protocol.

Ans: Have fixed the accidental typo under the ‘Base Information -> Description’ section.

2.	Can you explain what SDK(s) or frameworks you plan to use? 

Ans: Below are the major SDK(s) or frameworks we are using:

a.	LangGraph: Advanced state-based workflow orchestration with checkpointing and multi-agent coordination
b.	Boto3: AWS SDK for Python, specifically leveraging the Bedrock client for generative AI services
c.	Flask: REST API framework for exposing HTTP endpoints
d.     AWS Strands: For agentic AI framework.

3.	I see your MCP will run on Lambda. I know this is possible, but long-running searches and complex decision logic may be a problem. Could you confirm this or if there would be any other AWS services included? 

Ans: The runtime for workflows which we are planning to use, are well within the limits of the allowed lambda processing times. Below are some more details on the same:
a.	We have identified that workflow step count and prompt template complexity directly impact processing time. We have optimized both to ensure all requests complete well within AWS Lambda runtime limits.
b.	Workflows follow deterministic, pre-defined step sequences using LangGraph StateGraph, enabling predictable runtime estimation and consistent execution paths.
c.	We implemented retry mechanisms with configurable attempts and timeout controls for downstream tool invocations, including automatic token refresh and graceful failure handling to maintain processing time boundaries.
d.	We utilize asynchronous processing patterns, providing immediate acknowledgment to consumers while delivering results via pre-configured callback URLs, ensuring responsive API behavior regardless of workflow complexity.

4.	How do you plan to restrict access for other systems to call this MCP server? ie, from within your account only? Payments are sensitive, so I want to understand how to keep this private (besides the AIP authorizer).

Ans: We will follow the standard Delta patterns for serverless AWS applications. Some of them are mentioned as belows:

a.	We will be using centralized authorizer to allow access only to specific client IDs.
b.	Security groups can be leveraged to allow requests from only designated Delta CIDR ranges.
c.	The lambda is behind a private API Gateway with VPC endpoint policy enforcement. It is exposed by Route53 endpoint in the private Route53 hosted zone, which means it can only be accessed from within the Delta network.
d.	The lambda also lies within a private VPC environment deployed across private subnets in multiple AZs with no internet gateway access.

5. How will you restrict access to the data (i.e. limit the data that's visible to the specific user)? This is typically done by passing the user context to the backend knowledge base, etc.

Ans: In the current scope, we are only loading pre-processed versions of the Enterprise Payment domain knowledge documents in the Bedrock knowledgebase. All documents would undergo data classification review before ingestion. No PII/PCI or other sensitive information would be a part of the knowledgebase. It would not contain any transactional data. Based on the workflow, appropriate meta data will be appended to the prompts to target information extraction from specific documentation.
Only aggregated payments metrics will be pulled from the reporting database (non-pci) to analyze and format with LLM. No direct access for LLM to the metrics. No raw transaction data will be used in the scope of the application.

6. Will you offer and publish an MCP client/agent specific to your server?
No.
column40:
The Agent is being developed to address a growing need for intelligent, scalable, and domain-specific support within the Enterprise Payments ecosystem at Delta Air Lines.

Business Drivers:
1. Operational Efficiency: Teams frequently require quick access to payment-related data, test information, and troubleshooting support. The Agent reduces manual effort and accelerates response times.
2. Domain Expertise at Scale: Acts as a digital SME, making Enterprise Payments knowledge accessible across teams and platforms.
3. Improved Decision-Making: Enables faster, more informed decisions by providing contextual insights and data-driven recommendations.
4. Cross-Platform Accessibility: Supports integration with MS Teams, proprietary Delta UIs, Amazon Q, and other LLM ecosystems, ensuring broad usability.

Technical Reasons
1. Automated SQL Generation: Reduces dependency on manual query writing and speeds up data retrieval. Note: Any automated SQL generated won't be allowed to run automatically against the database. Only pre-defined SQL queries can run.
2. Test Data Access: Simplifies validation and QA processes by providing structured test data insights.
3. Secure Architecture: Designed with Zero Trust principles and compliant with Delta’s AI mandates, ensuring safe deployment and usage.
4. Scalability & Maintainability: Owned and maintained by the Enterprise Payments team, ensuring alignment with domain needs and long-term sustainability.

This product fills a critical gap by combining AI capabilities with deep domain knowledge, enabling faster, smarter, and more secure operations across the Enterprise Payments landscape.
column41:
The Agent delivers significant business value by enhancing operational efficiency, reducing manual effort, and accelerating access to domain-specific insights within the Enterprise Payments function at Delta Air Lines.

Key Business Benefits:
1. Time Savings: Automates responses to frequently asked questions, SQL generation, and test data retrieval—reducing dependency on SMEs and manual data analysis. Note: Any automated SQL generated won't be allowed to run automatically against the database. Only pre-defined SQL queries can run.
2. Improved Productivity: Enables faster troubleshooting and decision-making across teams, freeing up resources for higher-value tasks.
3. Scalable Expertise: Acts as a digital SME, making Enterprise Payments knowledge accessible across platforms and teams.
4. Cross-Platform Integration: Supports MS Teams, proprietary Delta UIs, Amazon Q, and other LLM ecosystems, increasing reach and usability.

ROI & Cost Savings:
1. Reduced SME Load: Estimated reduction in SME support hours by up to 30–40%, translating into measurable cost savings.
2. Faster Issue Resolution: Shortened turnaround time for data access and query generation, improving operational throughput.
3. Lower Training Costs: New team members can leverage the Agent for onboarding and domain understanding, reducing formal training overhead.
4. Minimized Errors: Automated SQL generation and guided data access reduce the risk of manual errors and rework. Note: Any automated SQL generated won't be allowed to run automatically against the database. Only pre-defined SQL queries can run.

1. Intelligent Query Resolution

    - Designed with Zero Trust principles and aligned with Delta’s AI mandates.

7. Scalable Support Model
    - Enables 24/7 support for payment-related queries and data access, improving responsiveness and reducing operational bottlenecks.
column43:
All data processed by the Agent will be stored and handled in accordance with Delta Air Lines’ Information Security Policies and AI mandates.

1. No PII or PCI data will be passed into or stored by the system.
2. Data used for query generation, test data insights, and model interactions will be processed within Delta-approved secure environments.
3. If leveraging platforms like AWS Bedrock, data will be processed using AI-specific controls such as Bedrock Guardrails, and Model Invocation Logging will be enabled.
4. All code, model artifacts, and configurations will be stored in Delta GitLab with proper access controls.
5. Any custom-developed or fine-tuned models (if used) will be stored in tamper-proof, encrypted archives within Delta’s secure infrastructure.

The system architecture follows Zero Trust principles, ensuring that all data access and processing is tightly controlled, monitored, and compliant with enterprise standards.

column65:
Architecture Overview
The Agent is designed to be a scalable, secure, and intelligent assistant for the Enterprise Payments domain. It leverages:

Amazon Bedrock for LLM capabilities and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) via Knowledge Bases:
1. AWS OpenSearch for fast, indexed search across structured and semi-structured data
2. Delta GitLab for secure version control of code and model artifacts
3. Zero Trust principles and AI-specific controls to ensure compliance with Delta’s InfoSec mandates

Architectural Strengths:
1. Modular & Scalable Design: Decoupled components allow easy scaling and future enhancements (e.g., adding new data sources or LLMs)
2. Secure by Design: No PII/PCI data processed
3. Guardrails, logging, and encryption built into Bedrock and OpenSearch: Compliant with Amber/Emerald mandates and AI governance policies
4. Cross-Platform Integration: UI-agnostic architecture supports MS Teams, proprietary Delta apps, Amazon Q, and other LLM ecosystems
5. High Availability & Resilience: AWS-native services support HA/DR configurations aligned with application criticality

Additional Information as requested:

c. Flask: REST API framework for exposing HTTP endpoints
