Ans: The runtime for workflows which we are planning to use, are well within the limits of the allowed lambda processing times. Below are some more details on the same:
a. We have identified that workflow step count and prompt template complexity directly impact processing time. We have optimized both to ensure all requests complete well within AWS Lambda runtime limits.
b. Workflows follow deterministic, pre-defined step sequences using LangGraph StateGraph, enabling predictable runtime estimation and consistent execution paths.
c. We implemented retry mechanisms with configurable attempts and timeout controls for downstream tool invocations, including automatic token refresh and graceful failure handling to maintain processing time boundaries.
d. We utilize asynchronous processing patterns, providing immediate acknowledgment to consumers while delivering results via pre-configured callback URLs, ensuring responsive API behavior regardless of workflow complexity.

4. How do you plan to restrict access for other systems to call this MCP server? ie, from within your account only? Payments are sensitive, so I want to understand how to keep this private (besides the AIP authorizer). 

Ans: We will follow the standard Delta patterns for serverless AWS applications. Some of them are mentioned as belows:

a. We will be using centralized authorizer to allow access only to specific client IDs.
b. Security groups can be leveraged to allow requests from only designated Delta CIDR ranges.
c. The lambda is behind a private API Gateway with VPC endpoint policy enforcement. It is exposed by Route53 endpoint in the private Route53 hosted zone, which means it can only be accessed from within the Delta network.
d. The lambda also lies within a private VPC environment deployed across private subnets in multiple AZs with no internet gateway access.

5. How will you restrict access to the data (i.e. limit the data that's visible to the specific user)? This is typically done by passing the user context to the backend knowledge base, etc.

Ans: In the current scope, we are only loading pre-processed versions of the Enterprise Payment domain knowledge documents in the Bedrock knowledgebase. All documents would undergo data classification review before ingestion. No PII/PCI or other sensitive information would be a part of the knowledgebase. It would not contain any transactional data. Based on the workflow, appropriate meta data will be appended to the prompts to target information extraction from specific documentation.
Only aggregated payments metrics will be pulled from the reporting database (non-pci) to analyze and format with LLM. No direct access for LLM to the metrics. No raw transaction data will be used in the scope of the application.

6. Will you offer and publish an MCP client/agent specific to your server?
No.
column85: The Agent for Enterprise Payments is fully compliant with Delta Air Lines' AI mandates and Information Security policies. Key compliance highlights include: 1. No PII or PCI data is processed or stored by the system. 2. The server follows the Path to Production (P2P) process and adheres to Amber and Emerald mandates. 3. Zero Trust architecture and secure-by-design principles are applied. 4. AI-specific controls (e.g., Bedrock Guardrails) are implemented where applicable. 5. A threat model is maintained, and model usage is logged for security monitoring. 6. All code and artifacts are stored in Delta GitLab with proper access controls. 7. Human-in-the-loop mechanisms are in place for critical decisions and deployments. 8. The system is integrated with Delta’s standard deployment automation, HA/DR planning, and InfoSec governance processes. 9. AI models and proprietary data are classified and protected as “Restricted” per policy. Ownership and maintenance of the Agent remain solely with the Enterprise Payments team, ensuring domain expertise and accountability.

column84: Vendor will support SAML 2.0 and they have MFA in place and PW management of 8char min, alphanumeric, periodic change requirement, no re-use of last 3 PW, 3 failed attempts lock out, self-service re-store feature, unused accounts disabled for direct access accounts as former employees continue to have access to the vendor solution. The vendor also has an app that supports ID/PW w/MFA but not SSO. Restated and below is as provided in email 9/30/2025 11:33pmCT to Brett et al. The vendor supports SAML 2.0 for their website and has confirmed they will integrate with Global Auth for that experience. Once an employee accesses the site, they are prompted to create an account—consistent with standard practices across most health and welfare benefit platforms. This account setup includes a unique ID/password and multi-factor authentication (MFA). In addition to SAML and MFA, the vendor enforces the following password management policies: Minimum 8-character length Alphanumeric requirement Periodic password change No reuse of the last 3 passwords Lockout after 3 failed login attempts Self-service password restore capability For account lifecycle management, unused direct access accounts are disabled. However, former employees may retain access to the vendor’s solution, which is something to note from a governance perspective. The vendor also offers a mobile app, which does not support SAML/SSO. However, it does require authentication using the locally created credentials and enforces MFA.

To enable Enterprise plugins in Amazon Managed Grafana, linking your AWS account to a Grafana Labs account is required.

column9: The TrackJS AI Debugger sends sanitized runtime error data from web applications to OpenAI via TrackJS infrastructure for automated analysis and debugging suggestions. No user IDs or IP addresses are transmitted, and OpenAI does not use the data for model training. The debugger is fully hosted within the vendor’s SaaS environment and only activates when users opt in per error. Customers retain full control over feature usage and data sharing, ensuring GDPR compliance.
column40: The TrackJS AI Code Debugger addresses gaps in our current error diagnosis and resolution workflow for client-side web applications. As an enhancement to our existing TrackJS error monitoring tool, it provides faster error resolution and reduced debugging time which is especially important during production incidents.
column41:
Faster error resolution: automatically analyzes JavaScript errors with full context (stack traces, telemetry, browser info, user actions) and provides 
actionable fixes without manual investigation, improving mean time to restore critical customer-facing systems

Reduced debugging time: Delivers senior-level debugging insights instantly, eliminating hours spent diagnosing complex framework-specific issues, browser 
inconsistencies, and race conditions.

Knowledge transfer: Helps developers understand root causes of errors, particularly valuable for developer who are new to Delta or working with unfamiliar 
codebases.
column42:
1. Automatic AI-Powered Error Analysis
   - Automatically analyzes every JavaScript error captured by TrackJS without manual intervention
   - No configuration or button clicks required - insights appear immediately when viewing error reports

2. Context-Aware Debugging
   - Analyzes complete error context including:
     - Stack traces and source code
     - Custom metadata
     - Browser and device information
     - User action telemetry leading to the error
     - Console logs
     - Network request history
   - Provides specific root cause identification based on full execution context

3. Actionable Code Solutions
   - Generates specific code fixes tailored to the actual error
   - Provides defensive coding patterns to prevent recurrence
   - Adapts original source code with safety checks and corrections

4. Framework and Browser-Specific Intelligence
   - Identifies framework-specific issues (Angular, React, Vue, etc.)
   - Recognizes browser-specific quirks and security boundaries
   - Detects common patterns like hydration mismatches, race conditions, and cross-origin restrictions

5. Privacy-Safe Analysis
   - Anonymizes error data before AI processing
   - Removes user information and sensitive data
   - Does not train AI models on customer error data

6. Senior-Level Diagnostic Insights
   - Explains "why" errors occurred, not just "what" happened
   - Provides educational context to help developers understand underlying issues
   - Translates cryptic browser errors into plain-language explanations

7. Seamless Integration
   - Works within existing TrackJS error monitoring interface
   - No separate tools or workflows required
   - Available for all TrackJS account tiers and environments (development through production)
column43:
Data Processing:
- Error data is anonymized before being sent for AI analysis
- User information and sensitive data are stripped prior to processing
- Customer error data is not used to train AI models
- Processing occurs as part of the existing TrackJS error monitoring workflow

Data Residency:
- *Not explicitly documented on the product announcement page*
- Recommend contacting TrackJS directly or reviewing their Data Processing Agreement (DPA) available at: https://trackjs.com/dpa/
- Additional documentation may be available in their Security Policy: https://trackjs.com/security/

Data Storage and Residency:
- Primary data storage: Canada (hosted by OVH Limited)
- Backup storage: United States (hosted by AWS)

AI Debugger-Specific Processing:
- AI analysis provider: OpenAI, L.L.C. (San Francisco, California, USA)
- Activation: Only when users explicitly click the AI Debugger tab for a specific error
- Data sent: Sanitized error data with automatic removal of end-user IP addresses and usernames
- Retention: OpenAI retains data for maximum 30 days, then automatically deleted
- Training: Data is not used for AI model training
- Control: Feature is disabled by default; can be enabled/disabled by account administrators at any time

Sub-Processors and Locations:
1. OVH Limited (Canada) - Infrastructure hosting
2. Amazon Web Services (United States) - Backup storage
3. OpenAI, L.L.C. (United States) - AI debugging (only when feature is enabled)

Data Retention:
- Error data: 30 days
- AI-processed data: Maximum 30 days at OpenAI, then deleted
- Account data: Retained for duration of service agreement

International Data Transfers:
- Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) approved by the European Commission are in place for EEA data transfers
- Data Processing Agreement (DPA) available and executed with all customers
- Compliant with GDPR, CCPA, and other applicable data protection laws

Compliance Documentation Available:
- Terms of Service: https://trackjs.com/terms/
- Privacy Policy: https://trackjs.com/privacy/
- Security Policy: https://trackjs.com/security/
- Data Processing Agreement: https://trackjs.com/dpa/
column44:
Partial Overlap with Existing Tools:
- Dynatrace - Provides application performance monitoring (APM) and error tracking, but lacks AI-powered debugging analysis and detailed 
JavaScript-specific error context
- Quantum Metrics - Focuses on digital experience analytics and session replay, but does not provide code-level error debugging or AI-
assisted root cause analysis

Market Alternatives (not currently in use):
- Sentry - JavaScript error monitoring with basic stack traces, but no AI debugging capabilities
- Rollbar - Error tracking and monitoring, lacks AI-powered analysis
- Bugsnag - Error monitoring platform, no AI debugging features
- LogRocket - Session replay with error tracking, different focus than AI debugging
- New Relic - APM with error tracking, no specialized AI debugging assistant

Key Differentiators of TrackJS AI Debugger:
- Only solution providing AI-powered root cause analysis specifically for JavaScript errors
- Integrates with existing TrackJS error monitoring framework
- Provides context-aware code fixes based on complete error telemetry
- Framework-specific intelligence (Angular, React, Vue, etc.)
- No equivalent AI debugging capability exists in Dynatrace or Quantum Metrics

Conclusion:
While partial functionality exists in current tools (Dynatrace, Quantum Metrics) and market alternatives, no equivalent solution provides AI-powered JavaScript 
debugging with the same level of context-aware analysis, actionable code fixes, or integration with existing monitoring and triaging workflows. TrackJS AI Debugger fills a specific gap in our current toolset.
column45:
Alternative Approach:

Custom in-house development - Would require significant engineering resources to build error monitoring, telemetry collection, and AI integration from 
scratch and would lack the deep integration with the TrackJS workflows already in use.

column54:
No immediate retirement opportunities identified. The TrackJS AI Debugger complements rather than replaces existing tools.

Cost Avoidance/Savings Opportunities:
- Positive impact - Expected to reduce costs through:
  - Faster error resolution (reduced developer debugging time)
  - Decreased mean time to resolution (MTTR)
  - Prevention of recurring issues through better root cause understanding
  - Reduced production incidents through improved code quality
column58:
The primary operational risks involve data privacy and AI accuracy. To mitigate data privacy concerns, the AI Debugger automatically filters sensitive information
(IP addresses, usernames) before transmission to OpenAI, operates on an opt-in basis (disabled by default), and is governed by executed Data Processing 
Agreements and Standard Contractual Clauses. OpenAI retains data for a maximum of 30 days before automatic deletion and does not use it for model training. 
Regarding AI accuracy, all debugging recommendations are advisory only and require developer review before implementation, ensuring human oversight of all 
suggested code changes.

Secondary risks include service dependency and compliance concerns, both of which are low-impact. The AI Debugger is an optional enhancement that does not affect core error monitoring functionality. If OpenAI experiences an outage, developers can continue using standard TrackJS error reports for manual debugging. 

Compliance risk is mitigated through TrackJS acting as Data Processor (with our organization remaining Data Controller), clear prohibition on processing sensitive/regulated data, and the ability to disable the feature immediately through account settings without any technical impact or cost.

Overall risk assessment is low. The feature can be disabled instantly if concerns arise, requires no contractual commitment beyond our existing TrackJS agreement,
and provides strong rollback capabilities. We will conduct periodic reviews of AI analysis accuracy, monitor for data privacy incidents, and perform the standard vendor risk assessments to ensure ongoing compliance and risk management.
column61:
The AI Debugger requires no formal implementation or rollout plan as it is automatically available within our existing TrackJS subscription. Account 
administrators will enable the feature through account settings, making it immediately accessible to development teams already using TrackJS for error monitoring.
Adoption will be organic and developer-driven  -- when reviewing JavaScript errors in the TrackJS interface, developers can optionally click the AI Debugger tab to 
receive automated root cause analysis and code fix recommendations. We will communicate feature availability through internal development channels and encourage voluntary usage as a debugging assistance tool. Since the feature integrates seamlessly into existing workflows with zero configuration, no training, migration, or dedicated onboarding activities are required.
column62: Mainstream adoption will be driven by demonstrated value and developer experience rather than mandated usage. As early adopters use the AI Debugger and experience faster error resolution, we expect organic adoption through peer recommendations and visible efficiency gains. We will monitor usage patterns and gather developer feedback to assess effectiveness, sharing success stories and best practices through internal development communications. If the tool proves valuable during the initial adoption phase, we may incorporate AI Debugger usage into standard debugging workflows and development best practices documentation. However, given the feature's optional nature and zero incremental cost, there is no pressure for universal adoption; developers will continue using it based on individual preference and situational value, with usage naturally increasing as teams recognize time savings and improved debugging outcomes.
column63:
The primary constraint is that customers are prohibited from including sensitive personal data, special categories of data under GDPR, or regulated data (HIPAA, 
PCI-DSS, government identifiers) in error data that may be processed by the AI Debugger. While TrackJS implements automated filtering to remove IP addresses and 
usernames, our organization remains responsible for ensuring compliance with this restriction. Additional constraints include: the AI Debugger is JavaScript-
specific and only analyzes errors captured by TrackJS (not applicable to other programming languages or error sources); data sent to OpenAI is retained for up to 
30 days before deletion; and the feature requires internet connectivity to OpenAI's services in the United States. There are no licensing, user count, or usage 
volume restrictions within our existing TrackJS subscription.

column84: Important Context: TrackJS is an existing, approved SaaS vendor already in use for error monitoring. The AI Debugger is an additional feature within the existing platform, not a new SaaS implementation. Core compliance was established during initial TrackJS onboarding. COMPLIANT Mandates: S1 - End-to-End Encryption - COMPLIANT: - Data in transit: All data encrypted via SSL/TLS per TrackJS Security Policy - Data at rest: Encrypted storage at OVH Limited (Canada) and AWS (backup) - AI data transmission: Encrypted in transit to OpenAI - No direct integration with Delta systems for AI Debugger (one-way data flow from web applications) S2.A - Global Auth/MFA Integration - COMPLIANT: TrackJS user authentication already integrated with Delta Global Auth and MFA requirements (existing implementation from original TrackJS deployment) S2.B - Outbound API Credentials Management - NOT APPLICABLE: AI Debugger does not use outbound APIs from Delta to TrackJS. Error data is captured client-side via JavaScript agent in web applications. S2.C - Inbound API Authorization - NOT APPLICABLE: TrackJS does not make inbound API calls to Delta systems. Data flow is unidirectional (Delta applications → TrackJS). S2.D - AD Groups via SailPoint - COMPLIANT: TrackJS access controlled through Delta AD groups managed by SailPoint (existing implementation from original TrackJS deployment). S2.E - Least Privilege Authorization - COMPLIANT: TrackJS role-based access controls enforced. Account administrators manage feature enablement; general users have read-only access to error reports. AI Debugger access follows existing RBAC model. S3.A - No Direct Inbound Connections - COMPLIANT: TrackJS does not connect inbound to Delta data sources. JavaScript agent runs client-side in user browsers and sends data outbound to TrackJS infrastructure. S3.B - Data Connection Credentials - NOT APPLICABLE: No direct database or data source connections exist. TrackJS agent uses account tokens managed within TrackJS platform. S3.C - Data Minimization - COMPLIANT: - Only JavaScript error data sent to TrackJS (stack traces, browser info, error context) - AI Debugger further sanitizes data (removes IP addresses, usernames) before OpenAI processing - Customer configurable to control data collection scope per TrackJS documentation - No bulk data uploads or database synchronization S4 - Logging Requirements - COMPLIANT: - TrackJS provides logging for user logins, administrative changes, and AI Debugger usage - All AI analysis requests logged per error reviewed - Audit trail available through TrackJS dashboard - Security incident notification per DPA Section 4.2 S5 - Network Access Restrictions - COMPLIANT: - Business Requirement Established: Developers require access to TrackJS from outside Delta network for incident response, remote work, and operational needs (existing approved use case) - CASB Protection: TrackJS access is protected by CASB (Cloud Access Security Broker) per item S3 with MFA enabled. - No Additional Restrictions Required: Public Internet access permitted due to business need and CASB protection
column85: Important Context: TrackJS AI Debugger is a third-party SaaS vendor product, not a custom-developed AI system. We are consumers of the AI capability, not developers or operators of the AI model. Many mandates apply to the vendor (TrackJS/OpenAI) rather than our organization. COMPLIANT Mandates: AI1 - Information Security Policies Compliance - COMPLIANT: TrackJS AI Debugger will follow standard Path to Production process for vendor tool adoption through this governance review. AI4 - Risk Tolerance & Human-in-the-Loop - COMPLIANT: AI provides advisory recommendations only; developers review and approve all code changes before implementation. Human-in-the-loop is enforced by design and there is no capability to directly change code without human intervention. AI6 - Contractual Language - COMPLIANT: TrackJS has executed Data Processing Agreement (DPA) with Standard Contractual Clauses and AI-specific terms. AI7 - Model Protection - VENDOR RESPONSIBILITY: OpenAI manages and protects AI models. TrackJS does not provide access to underlying models. AI8 - Proprietary Training Data Protection - COMPLIANT: OpenAI does not use our error data for model training per contractual terms. We do not train or fine-tune models. AI9 - Logging & Visibility - COMPLIANT: All AI Debugger usage is logged within TrackJS platform. Each AI analysis request is tracked per error reviewed. AI15 - Supply Chain Evaluation - COMPLIANT: TrackJS and OpenAI contracts include Information Security Addendum. DPA executed with data protection terms. AI17 - Input Validation & Sanitization - COMPLIANT: TrackJS automatically sanitizes data (removes IP addresses, usernames) before transmission to OpenAI. Additional validation enforced through data classification policies. AI18 - Behavior Monitoring - VENDOR RESPONSIBILITY: OpenAI monitors for adversarial attacks and abuse. TrackJS logs all usage for audit purposes. AI19 - Security Breach Notification - COMPLIANT: DPA requires TrackJS to notify of security incidents. Standard incident response procedures apply. AI20 - Minimal Data Return - COMPLIANT: AI returns only debugging insights specific to the error analyzed. No bulk data extraction capability. AI22 - HA/DR Requirements - COMPLIANT: AI Debugger is optional, non-critical feature. Core error monitoring (TrackJS) has vendor-managed HA/DR. AI outage does not impact operations. NOT APPLICABLE Mandates (Third-Party SaaS Model): AI2 - Platform-Specific Controls (AWS Bedrock) - NOT APPLICABLE: Does not use AWS Bedrock. Uses OpenAI API via TrackJS integration. AI3 - Zero Trust Architecture - VENDOR RESPONSIBILITY: TrackJS/OpenAI implement Zero Trust. We enforce access controls at account level. AI5 - Threat Model Maintenance - VENDOR RESPONSIBILITY: OpenAI maintains threat model for their AI system. We assess vendor risk through procurement process. AI10 - Cryptographic Model Verification - VENDOR RESPONSIBILITY: We do not develop or fine-tune models. OpenAI manages model integrity. AI11 - Model Archival - VENDOR RESPONSIBILITY: We do not develop or fine-tune models. OpenAI manages model versioning. AI12 - Version Control for Models - VENDOR RESPONSIBILITY: We do not develop models. No model artifacts to store in GitLab. AI13 - Model Testing & Validation - VENDOR RESPONSIBILITY: OpenAI tests and validates their models. We evaluate output quality through usage. AI14 - Automated Deployments - NOT APPLICABLE: No deployment required. Feature enabled via account settings toggle. AI16 - Secure Development Zone Testing - VENDOR RESPONSIBILITY: We do not import or run models. OpenAI operates models in their infrastructure. AI21 - Security Audits & Penetration Testing - VENDOR RESPONSIBILITY: OpenAI conducts security testing. TrackJS provides audit reports upon request per DPA Section 4.4. KEY COMPLIANCE NOTES: 1. This is a vendor-provided AI service, not custom development 2. We do not train, fine-tune, or operate AI models 3. Human oversight is built into the workflow (advisory only) 4. Standard vendor risk management and procurement processes apply 5. Data sanitization occurs before AI processing 6. Feature can be disabled immediately if compliance concerns arise

column9: The UiPath Agentic AI Component empowers the creation of intelligent, autonomous agents that combine large language model (LLM) reasoning, robotic process automation (RPA), and API execution to perform complex tasks with minimal human input. These agents operate using a structured framework of prompts, context, tools, and escalation paths, enabling dynamic decision-making, memory retention, and secure execution. Designed for scalable enterprise automation, the component supports low-code and full-code development, making it ideal for use cases such as customer service automation, data summarization, and intelligent triage across systems.

column40:
The UiPath Agentic AI Component is needed to address the growing demand for intelligent automation that can adapt to dynamic business environments with minimal human oversight. Traditional RPA solutions often rely on rigid workflows and predefined rules, limiting their ability to handle complex, unstructured tasks. Business drivers include the need for scalable automation, improved operational efficiency, and enhanced customer experience through autonomous decision-making. Technically, this component leverages large language models (LLMs), contextual memory, and tool orchestration to enable agents that can reason, act, and escalate intelligently. It supports low-code and full-code development, making it a versatile solution for IT operations, customer service, and data processing use cases.

The Cargo Customer Support team faces operational inefficiencies due to high email volume (4,000–5,000 daily) and duplicate case creation from follow-up messages on the same issue. This leads to backlog, missed SLAs, and reduced customer satisfaction. The proposed POC will leverage UiPath Agentic AI to intelligently analyze email intent and context, enabling accurate case categorization, duplicate case linking, and streamlined agent routing. Expected outcomes include improved SLA compliance, faster resolution times, reduced agent workload, and enhanced customer experience—ultimately boosting NPS and brand trust.
column41: The UiPath Agentic AI Component delivers significant business value by enabling intelligent automation that reduces manual effort, accelerates decision-making, and improves operational efficiency. By leveraging AI-driven agents capable of reasoning, learning, and acting autonomously, organizations can streamline complex workflows, reduce response times, and minimize human intervention in repetitive or data-intensive tasks. This leads to cost savings, improved scalability, and enhanced customer satisfaction. Additionally, the component supports flexible integration with existing systems and tools, making it easier to adapt to evolving business needs and drive innovation across departments.

For enterprise deployments, UiPath provides SLAs, incident management, and escalation paths through its customer success and technical account management teams. Additionally, the Agentic AI Component integrates with UiPath’s governance and observability tools, allowing IT teams to monitor agent behavior, manage exceptions, and ensure compliance with organizational policies.

Quvia will access the Panasonic Operational data that is being collected in the TechOps Data Lake for Confidential Data. Additionally, the application will generate maintenance alarms and alerts for corrective action.

column40: Quvia web application visualizes Panasonic IFE operational data collected from each flight.  It accesses the Panasonic Operational data that is being collected in the TechOps Data Lake for Confidential Data.  The app establishes a Quality of Experience (QoE) score of the IFE operations per seat, flight, aircraft, and fleets.  Additionally, the application generates maintenance alarms and alerts for corrective action. The current process for maintenance of the Panasonic IFE system relies heavily on defects being identified by the Delta passengers and flight crews.  Maintenance Log Pages are generated by the pilots and flight crews for resolution.
column41: The primary benefits of this IFE QoE tool are to identify defects before significant passenger impacts, improve the system network health for improved customer NSAT, arm the aircraft mechanic with prescribed maintenance actions that will yield shorter defect durations and improve first time fix rate.
column42: The IFE QoE tool consumes the Panasonic system operational performance data, post flight.  There are events captured within this performance data that identify out of bounds conditions which require maintenance actions.  Rules, signatures, and algorithms have been developed within the IFE QoE tool to curate this post flight data and identify specific events that are passenger impacting and provide prescribed maintenance actions for these impacting events.
column43:
The Panasonic IFE data is residing in the Clickhouse cloud on Quvia's side.
The Logpage data is kept in SCEPTRE/IMS DB. Quvia doesn't store any PII info.

column9: This SaaS app is a tool that records and provides a real-time transcript of the audio discussion, typically within several minutes after the recording is concluded. It is used by the CEO Communications to provide fast, accurate transcripts of Ed’s public speaking and media interviews to Ed, as well as the Delta media team and Investor Relations. Transcripts are also provided on occasion to Government Affairs when relevant (if the event is in Washington, for example, or an interview with political media like Politico or the Washington Post). The CEO team uses the tool solely for transcribing and its use is limited to public events or on-the-record media interviews with Ed. It is not used to record internal Delta meetings or any event where private or proprietary information is discussed. The recording is always done using the IOS app on one of the team’s phones, and it is occasionally accessed via the browser from a Surface to review and edit the transcript before it is sent to Ed and other relevant stakeholders.

column9:
Delta has been invited by AWS to be included in a private beta test of a new agentic tool called AWS SEG (Super Elastic Gumby). SEG is similar to Q CLI in that it is an Agentic CLI tool that is designed for large scale code transformations, code interpretations, repeatable code updates (ie upgrade node version, java version, python version. There are several uses cases that during this preview we are looking to evaluate SEG for delta use cases:
1. Dependency Mapping. Currently there is a gap at Delta to understand what App/Api/Component is calling or dependent on what. 
2. Code Library upgrades. Currently there are several teams that need to upgrade node and python versions. This is one of SEG core use cases to upgrade to latest versions of major frameworks
3. Code summarization: Developer Hub team has an immediate need to onboard existing gitlab repo's/applications into DeveloperHub. To do this we are looking for an agent tool (SEG) to provide the summary of the application so that we can understand the application type and components needed for onboarding
4. Code Library Dependencies: As part of the move from Veracode to Gitlab SAST scans, Security is needing a lockfile added to every repo. Java package managers do not have a concept of this like Node. We are looking at SEG to iterate thru the gitlab repos and create this file to automate this need for the migration
column25:
9/7/25: STR approved
PIA not required for agentic tool but would be required for the app calling this
We are looking for access to the private beta for a 6-month POC to evaluate the above use cases. We would like to have access added to the following AWS account: devexp-dev-653874357086 (653874357086)

column9:
LISA Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open protocol that enables seamless integration between LLM applications and external data sources and tools (Sumologic in this case). It standardizes how applications provide context to LLMs. MCP provides a standardized way to connect AI models to different data sources and tools. It helps build agents and complex workflows on top of LLMs. MCP provides a standardized way for applications to:
1. Pre-built integrations that LLMs can directly plug into
2. Share contextual information with language models
3. Expose tools and capabilities to AI systems
4. Build composable integrations and workflows
5. Best practices for securing your data within your infrastructure

Future integrations include Agility/V1 , PagerDuty, Gitlab, AWS RDS, IBM Db2 , ServiceNow
column25:
The LISA MCP (Model Context Protocol) Server is fully compliant with Delta Air Lines' AI mandates and Information Security policies. Key compliance highlights include:

1. No PII or PCI data is processed or stored by the system.
2. The server follows the Path to Production (P2P) process and adheres to Amber and Emerald mandates.
3. Zero Trust architecture and secure-by-design principles are applied.
4. AI-specific controls (e.g., Bedrock Guardrails) are implemented where applicable.
5. A threat model is maintained, and model usage is logged for security monitoring.
6. All code and artifacts are stored in Delta GitLab with proper access controls.
7. Human-in-the-loop mechanisms are in place for critical decisions and deployments.
8. The system is integrated with Delta’s standard deployment automation, HA/DR planning, and InfoSec governance processes.
9. AI models and proprietary data are classified and protected as “Restricted” per policy.

Ownership and maintenance of the MCP server remain solely with the Alliance team, ensuring domain expertise and accountability.
column40:
LISA's local MCP (Model Context Protocol) server which provides tools to interact with your Sumologic account, allowing you to manage logs, analysis, schedules, and more directly from your MCP-enabled client.

The "LISA MCP Server" refers to a server that acts as a bridge between Large Language Models (LLMs) and Sumologic API,. This allows LLMs to interact with and manage various Sumologic resources programmatically,
Using the Sumologic MCP Server allows programmatic interaction with Sumologic resources via structured inputs and outputs, which is beneficial for LLMs.

IT teams are rapidly adopting AI for convenience and efficiency in their day-to-day work.  We need AI to bring context and suggest precise root cause, generate tests automatically, auto-collect information to fix vulnerabilities, and recommend optimizations based on real production insights.

Enhanced incident response by allowing Sumologic to quickly integrate information from logging systems, and correlate it with existing code
Unified workflows by facilitating cross-platform data access and integration from other systems.
Intelligent pattern recognition.debugging through AI-created summary based on patterns and contextual data.
Comprehensive reporting and analytics through aggregated data from multiple sources.

column9:
The agent for the Agility Coaching Office (ACO) at Delta Air Lines is a conversational assistant designed to help Agile practitioners quickly access guidance on Agile processes. It uses the ACO SharePoint knowledgebase to answer queries from Product Owners, Business Analysts, Scrum Masters, and other team members, promoting consistency and efficiency across the organization.

Key Capabilities:

1. Answers Agile-related queries using ACO SharePoint documentation.
2. Supports onboarding and consistent Agile practices across teams.
3. Handles questions on epics, features, user stories, and definitions of done.
4. Integrates with VersionOne for story tracking and board hygiene.
5. Automates sprint board checks, KPI monitoring, and release tagging.
6. Includes MCP Gateway, REST API, workflow orchestration, and agent registry.
7. Serves Product Owners, Business Analysts, Scrum Masters, TPMs, and Engineers.
column25:
1. It is designed to be UI-agnostic, supporting integration with platforms like MS Teams, Delta proprietary applications, Amazon Q, and other LLM ecosystems.
2. The agent is owned and maintained solely by the Agile Coaching Office team, ensuring domain expertise and operational control.

I see in the diagram that you are doing a KB from payments SharePoint. You need to clarify why you need to ingest payments SharePoint for this MCP Server - this is an Agent and not an MCP server.
Response : We would be fetching data from ACO SharePoint, it was a copy paste error earlier, I’ve updated the architecture as well.

Why do you need the OpenSearch database in front of the knowledgebase. LLM responses in general aren't very fast so adding in the extra latency on the search vs costs doesn't seem to be worth it here
Response: We have completed the POC with our use case and waiting on the Bedrock access in our account. Post the STR approval with subsequent grant for the Bedrock Access in the ACO AWS account, we will evaluate the options for accessing the knowledgebase by the OpenSearch layer or without it.

It’s not clear how the MCP Server will be interacting with bedrock. From the use case it seems like the Agent interacting with the LLM would be Q CLI or whatever is calling this mcp server
Response: The ACO MCP server lambda will act as a central orchestrator for any LLM/agentic AI related use cases related to the ACO and will thus be scalable. The ACO MCP server can be accessed via any interface like Amazon Q, proprietary UI, etc.
column40:
Agile practitioners across Delta Air Lines face challenges accessing consistent, role-specific guidance on Agile processes. The new agent addresses this gap by providing an intelligent, conversational interface that delivers instant answers using the ACO SharePoint knowledgebase. It supports onboarding, continuous learning, and operational efficiency for Product Owners, Business Analysts, Scrum Masters, and other Agile roles.

1. Streamlined Access to Agile Knowledge: The Agent reduces dependency on manual coaching by offering immediate, contextual responses to common Agile queries (e.g., epics, user stories, definitions of done) using ACO documentation.
2. Consistency Across Teams: It promotes standardized Agile practices across domains and squads, aligning with Delta’s shift from project-based to product-based delivery models.
3. Enhanced Learning & Upskilling: Supports Delta’s upskilling journeys for Agile roles through embedded guidance and integration with tools like VersionOne.
4. Operational Efficiency: Automates routine tasks such as story creation, board hygiene monitoring, and KPI tracking, freeing up time for strategic work.
5. Governance Compliance: Meets Agent build requirements including STR approval and domain consent, ensuring alignment with Delta’s IT governance standards.
column41:
The agent enhances Delta’s Agile transformation by providing instant, reliable access to Agile knowledge and practices. It supports Agile roles across the enterprise—Product Owners, Scrum Masters, Business Analysts—by streamlining onboarding, reducing coaching overhead, and promoting consistent delivery excellence.

1. Accelerates Learning & Onboarding: New team members can quickly understand Agile concepts like epics, features, and user story formats without waiting for manual coaching.
2. Promotes Consistency: Ensures standardized Agile practices across squads and domains, aligned with Delta’s shift from project-based to product-based delivery.
3. Improves Efficiency: Automates routine tasks such as story creation, board hygiene monitoring, and KPI tracking, freeing up time for strategic work.
4. Supports Agile Culture: Reinforces Delta’s Agile mindset—transparency, collaboration, trust, and continuous improvement—by embedding guidance into daily workflows.
5. Scales Agile Coaching: Reduces dependency on individual coaches by making ACO SharePoint knowledge accessible through a conversational interface.
6. Aligns with Strategic Goals: Helps squads deliver value faster and adapt to change, supporting Delta’s business strategy and planning ecosystem.

column43:
All data processed by the agent will be stored and handled in accordance with Delta Air Lines’ Information Security Policies and AI mandates.

1. No PII or PCI data will be passed into or stored by the system.
2. Data used for query generation, test data insights, and model interactions will be processed within Delta-approved secure environments.
3. If leveraging platforms like AWS Bedrock, data will be processed using AI-specific controls such as Bedrock Guardrails, and Model Invocation Logging will be enabled.
4. All code, model artifacts, and configurations will be stored in Delta GitLab with proper access controls.
5. Any custom-developed or fine-tuned models (if used) will be stored in tamper-proof, encrypted archives within Delta’s secure infrastructure.

The system architecture follows Zero Trust principles, ensuring that all data access and processing is tightly controlled, monitored, and compliant with enterprise standards.

column65:
Architecture Overview
The GenAI Agent is designed to be a scalable, secure, and intelligent assistant for the ACO domain. It leverages:

Amazon Bedrock for LLM capabilities and retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) via Knowledge Bases:
1. AWS OpenSearch for fast, indexed search across structured and semi-structured data
2. Delta GitLab for secure version control of code and model artifacts
3. Zero Trust principles and AI-specific controls to ensure compliance with Delta’s InfoSec mandates

Architectural Strengths:
1. Modular & Scalable Design: Decoupled components allow easy scaling and future enhancements (e.g., adding new data sources or LLMs)
2. Secure by Design: No PII/PCI data processed
3. Guardrails, logging, and encryption built into Bedrock and OpenSearch: Compliant with Amber/Emerald mandates and AI governance policies
4. Cross-Platform Integration: UI-agnostic architecture supports MS Teams, proprietary Delta apps, Amazon Q, and other LLM ecosystems
5. High Availability & Resilience: AWS-native services support HA/DR configurations aligned with application criticality

column9:
Purpose: Test an AI-driven contract review tool co-developed with Supply Chain to validate value before committing to a full implementation.

Pilot Approach: Uses live Delta contracts (not generic data) to ensure realistic results. Supply Chain will co-develop with AlixPartners in their secure Azure environment, leveraging open-source libraries and segregated LLM deployments. Access secured via Delta SSO and MFA for controlled collaboration.

Data Handling: Delta contract data will temporarily reside in AlixPartners’ environment, protected by enterprise-grade security controls and governed by NDAs/MSAs.

Next Steps: If the pilot demonstrates value, the solution will undergo a new approval process for permanent deployment and transition to Delta’s AWS environment.

-Managing complex supplier contracts
-Identifying risks aligned with Delta’s operating model

column41:

Enterprise Vision:
-Delta plans to implement this Generative AI solution across the enterprise for all third-party supplier contracts.
-Delta seeks a strategic partner to co-build the solution, with the goal of Delta owning and managing the platform independently once established.

column1: AWS Strands Library (for Generative AI Patterns)
column9:
AWS Strands is an open-source SDK that allows developers to build autonomous AI agents using a model-first approach. While it integrates with AWS services, it is not a service provided by AWS itself.

The Enterprise AI and CCoE teams are collaborating to develop a suite of Generative AI Patterns on AWS to be consumed across other teams in Delta. These patterns will provide modular, reusable building blocks that can be integrated into their projects without deep AI/ ML expertise.​
The first three patterns that will be developed are as follows:​
Summarization Pattern - To enable users to receive concise summaries of their documents​
Database Chatbot Pattern – To enable users to analyze and query their data in natural language.​
Retrieval-Augmented-Generation Pattern – To enable users to ingest and index enterprise data, enabling LLMs to retrieve and ground responses in Delta-specific knowledge.​

AWS Strands library has been identified as a good fit for agent orchestration in the solution.
column25: 9/17/25: STR approved
column40:
AWS Strands is an open-source SDK library developed by AWS for building LLM-powered agents. It provides a standardized, model-driven framework for orchestrating AI workflows and multi-agent systems. Without Strands, developers must handcraft orchestration logic or rely on third-party frameworks that are less aligned with AWS. Adopting Strands ensures we use an AWS-native, open-source, and well-supported framework for building agentic applications.
The AI team is building Gen AI solution patterns (Summarization, Database Chatbot, and RAG) that will be provisioned across multiple tenant accounts via AWS Service Catalog. Strands is a good fit for the orchestration layer for the patterns.
column41:
Standardization: Establishes a single, AWS-supported framework for agentic AI development.
Future-proofing: Maintains compatibility with Amazon Bedrock and other AWS services.
Faster delivery: Reduces time spent on boilerplate orchestration code.
Cost efficiency: No licensing costs; reduces redundant engineering effort.
Governance: Confidence in long-term support from AWS compared to other third-party solutions.
column42:
Agent orchestration: Define and run single or multi-agent GenAI workflows.
Tool integration: Connect agents with APIs, databases, or enterprise systems.
Model flexibility: Works with Bedrock models (Titan, Claude, etc.)
Multi-agent collaboration: Enables complex workflows where multiple agents interact.
column43:
The data will be stored and processed within AWS (S3, Dynamo DB etc.)

The current development of patterns is in the Gen AI Dev account - genai-dev-867752000777
As the patterns get published to AWS service catalog and is requested by internal consumers, the data and processing will be in the respective tenant accounts.
column44:
LangChain (open-source agent and orchestration library).
LlamaIndex (focus on data-to-agent pipelines).
Haystack (framework for RAG and NLP workflows).
Custom-built orchestration logic (in-house frameworks).

Since Strands is an AWS offering, it ensures we use an AWS-native, open-source, and well-supported framework for building agentic applications
column45:
1) Use third-party frameworks like LangChain
2) Develop custom orchestration code
column46:
Zero licensing cost (Strands is free under Apache 2.0)
Minimal engineering effort to integrate into our solution
column50: Existing support from AWS is applicable to Strands as well, since this is an AWS offering
column51: The support the AWS will continue for this service as it does for any other AWS offerings in Delta
column53:
Skills:
Development teams require only Python proficiency and familiarity with AWS services (Lambda, Bedrock, etc.).
Tooling:
No new tooling is introduced beyond standard Python package management (pip, requirements.txt).
Integrates seamlessly with existing CI/CD pipelines, infrastructure as code (CloudFormation/CDK), and AWS-native services.
Ownership:
Internal ownership sits with the internal teams deploying Strands-powered solutions.
Strands itself is supported by AWS via the open-source repository, reducing the need for a dedicated product owner internally.
column54: Duplication of effort across teams (e.g., each team building its own summarizer/chatbot orchestration) can be retired, with Strands providing a single, standardized framework.
column61:
Pilot scope: Adopt AWS Strands within a limited number of use cases, identified for testing the Gen AI Patterns.
Targeted patterns: Start with 3 patterns - Summarization, Database chatbot, and RAG to validate Strands’ integration.
Controlled rollout:  Publish approved Strands-powered patterns into the AWS Service Catalog for self-service provisioning by business units on to specific accounts.
column62:
Enterprise rollout: Publish Strands-powered patterns into the AWS Service Catalog for self-service provisioning for all accounts.
Scale to multi-agent workflows: Expand adoption beyond initial pilots to advanced use cases (multi-agent collaboration, cross-service orchestration)
column65:
Strands offers a curated set of modular blueprints and orchestration tools that accelerate experimentation with common Gen AI patterns—such as retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), Summarization Pattern, Database chatbot. Its integration with AWS-native services (e.g., Bedrock, Lambda, S3 bucket, DynamoDB) simplifies deployment and scaling, while also supporting rapid iteration and observability.

Using Strands can help reduce setup time, enforce architectural consistency, and provide reusable components across multiple Gen AI initiatives. I recommend for approval.

column9:
This STR is intended to enable the use of the Super Elastic Gumby product, currently available as part of an AWS beta service. We are evaluating this tool to determine its potential in supporting the decomposition and documentation of TPF source code.

Delta has been invited by AWS to be included in a private beta test of a new agentic tool called AWS SEG (Super Elastic Gumby). SEG is similar to Q CLI in that it is an Agentic CLI tool that is designed for large scale code transformations, code interpretations, repeatable code updates. There are several uses cases that during this preview we are looking to evaluate SEG for TPF mainframe legacy use cases:
1. Documentation : Currently there is a gap with the source code and business documentation that are decades old. 
2. Code migration/transformation. One of SEG core use cases to evaluate the possibility of code migration at scale.
column25: We are looking for access to the private beta for a 6 month POC to evaluate the above use cases. We would like to have access added to the following AWS account: ctt-dev-837793805125

column9:
OneTrust is a category-defining enterprise platform designed to help organizations operationalize trust across domains like:

Privacy & Consent Management
Data Governance
Ethics & Compliance
AI Governance
Third-Party Risk
ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance)

It supports modules such as:

Privacy Automation
Consent & Preference Management
AI Governance
GRC (Governance, Risk, Compliance)
DataGuidance
PreferenceChoice
column40:
Business Drivers
Global Privacy Compliance: OneTrust was selected as Delta’s Consent Management Platform (CMP) to ensure compliance with evolving global privacy laws. Non-compliance risks include fines up to 4% of annual revenue, reputational damage, and loss of customer trust. 
Customer Trust & Transparency: CMPs like OneTrust help build long-term customer relationships by enabling transparent data practices and honoring user consent preferences. 
Cost Avoidance: Automating consent capture and policy enforcement reduces manual overhead and mitigates risks tied to human error.

Technical Reasons
Integrates with tools like Adobe Experience Platform and ServiceNow.
Enables real-time consent tracking, AI governance, and data policy enforcement.
Supports SSO/MFA, REST APIs, and centralized reporting.
column41:
Business Benefits:
1. Compliance & Risk Mitigation:
- Ensures adherence to global privacy laws, avoiding fines up to 4% of annual revenue.
- Automates consent capture and policy enforcement, reducing manual errors and legal exposure.
2. Customer Trust & Experience:
- Builds long-term customer relationships by honoring consent preferences.
- Enables personalized experiences while respecting user privacy.
3. Operational Efficiency:
- Integrates with Adobe Analytics, Quantum Metric, and LivePerson to streamline data governance.
- Centralizes reporting and consent tracking across platforms.
ROI & Cost Savings:
1. Cost Avoidance:
- Prevents regulatory penalties and litigation costs through proactive compliance.
2. Vendor Optimization:
- Sunsetting vendors yields annual savings.
3. Advanced Reporting:
- Real-time dashboards and AI model governance improve decision-making and reduce operational
overhead.
column42:
Core Business Capabilities of OneTrust
1. Consent & Preference Management
Captures and centralizes user consent across web, mobile, and call center channels.
Automates compliance with global privacy laws (e.g., GDPR, CCPA).
Integrates with Adobe Experience Platform to sync consent flags with customer profiles.

2. AI Governance
Monitors AI model registration, performance, and compliance.
Provides transparency dashboards and model cards for risk evaluation.
Integrates with MLOps tools like SageMaker

3. Privacy & Data Governance
Automates privacy impact assessments and data mapping.
Identifies privacy risks and enforces controls across customer, employee, and vendor data.

4. Cookie Compliance
Uses Cloudflare CDN and geolocation services to manage cookie scripts.
Handles 40B+ requests weekly for cookielaw.org scripts. 

5. GRC (Governance, Risk, Compliance)

Supports policy and procedure management with role-based dashboards.
Enables attestation, version control, and analytics on policy usage.

6. Vendor Risk Management
Through OneTrust Vendorpedia, assesses third-party risk and compliance posture.
Tracks vendor contracts, certifications, and performance metrics. 

7. ESG & Ethics
Centralizes ESG reporting and ethical compliance workflows.
Enables cross-functional collaboration across legal, sustainability, and HR teams

column9:
Aircraft Condition Monitoring System (ACMS) is a system within all of our aircraft that generates reports (snapshot and full flight) of aircraft sensor data, which help fuel Delta’s Predictive Maintenance, Flight Safety, etc. programs. ACMS software is DO-178C Level E aircraft software, which means that it is classified as user modifiable software and has no effect on the safety or operation of the aircraft.

Tech Ops currently uses an off-network machine to develop and simulate ACMS aircraft software parts. Due to this machine getting old, we would like to bring this software to an IT-supported machine. We have procured a desktop computer (Watlcamp10857) and this product request form is to have the software that we use to simulate ACMS aircraft software parts, ACMS Tester, be installed onto the new machine. We already own the license to this software so purchase of this software is not required and would require minimal support from IT.
column40: This product allows us to evaluate new Aircraft Condition Monitoring System (ACMS) software prior to installing it on-wing.
column41: The data that the ACMS aircraft software part generates is used for reducing operational disruptions, reducing and investigating flight safety and maintenance events, fuel consumption reduction, and much more.
column42: Tech Ops currently uses an off-network machine to develop and test Aircraft Condition Monitoring System (ACMS) aircraft software parts.  Updates to this software help fuel Delta’s Predictive Maintenance program, Flight Safety program, Sustainability, Maintenance Control, etc. For example, this program allows us to evaluate updates to ACARS ACMS Reports and MCDU screens. ACMS aircraft software parts are DO-178C Level E aircraft software, which means that it is classified as airline modifiable software and lack of development has no effect on the safety or operation of the aircraft. This product allows us to evaluate the new software prior to installing it on-wing.

column9: Enterprise-ready Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers that enable Amazon Q Developer to directly connect and interact with databases (PostgreSQL, DB2), cache systems (Redis), version control (GitLab), and cloud services (AWS). Provides secure, real-time access to organizational data and infrastructure through natural language queries.
column25:
Technology: Node.js MCP servers using official Amazon MCP SDK
Databases: PostgreSQL (via Prisma), IBM DB2 (via ibm_db driver)
Authentication: Environment-based credential management
Deployment: Local installation, connects to existing infrastructure
Dependencies: Node.js 18+, npm packages for database drivers
Configuration: JSON-based configuration file in user's AWS directory
Testing: Built-in connection testing for all services

Security & Third-Party Dependencies:
No External Data Transfer: All connections are direct to internal infrastructure
Credential Security: Uses existing organizational credentials (no new accounts)
Third-Party Libraries: Standard database drivers (Prisma, ibm_db) and AWS SDK
Local Execution: Runs locally on developer machines, no cloud dependencies
No Internet Requirements: Works entirely within corporate network
column40: Developers spend significant time switching between multiple tools to access data - opening database clients for queries, AWS console for infrastructure, GitLab for repository information, and Redis CLI for cache operations. Additionally, developers must learn and remember complex SQL syntax, AWS CLI commands, and various tool-specific interfaces. This context switching and knowledge overhead reduces productivity and creates friction in development workflows.
column41:
Increased Developer Productivity: Reduce time spent switching between tools by 60-80%

Faster Problem Resolution: Instant access to database queries, logs, and infrastructure status

Reduced Learning Curve: Natural language interface eliminates need to remember complex SQL syntax or CLI commands

Improved Code Quality: Real-time access to production data enables better informed development decisions

Cost Efficiency: Maximize ROI on existing Amazon Q Developer licenses through enhanced capabilities

Standardized Access: Consistent interface across all organizational systems
column42:
Database Operations:
Execute SQL queries on PostgreSQL and DB2 using natural language
Browse table structures and relationships without database tools
Analyze data patterns and troubleshoot data issues in real-time

Infrastructure Management:

column1: OnDemand Video Interview with Automated Interview Scoring (adding Interview Intelligence insights)
column9: HireVue operates primarily in the software-as-a-service (SaaS) sector, providing a cloud-based platform that specializes in video interviewing and pre-employment assessment services designed to streamline the talent acquisition process.  This STR is to extend the capabilities of the HireVue solution to include the Interview Intelligence insights.
column25:
10/7/25: STR approved
Pending items: PIA, contract
HR PMO1319 project is Adding Interview Intelligence insights to existing AI product that was onboarded in STR: "902 - OnDemand Video Interview with Automated Interview Scoring"
column40:
Earlier this year, we received AI Governance approvals for HireVue OnDemand Video (ODV) interview with Automated Interview Scoring (AIS) [STR#902 Blockcode: HRMRAHODVS]. This scoring is enabled with machine learning and natural language processing, producing a recommended score from 1-5 for each video response. This score does not directly impact the candidate. A human evaluator sees the recommended score, but ultimately, the evaluator reviews the ODV and selects the score for the candidate.
We would like to add a complementary service offered by HireVue called “Interview Intelligence” to the scope with this project. NO NEW AI technology will be deployed. As a part of the NLP AI powering the AIS, the candidate’s responses are put into transcripts. Interview Intelligence would use this transcript, as well as the existing ML powering AIS, to provide the additional features outlined below. These features will provide additional clarity, transparency, and accountability for the recruiter as they review the candidate’s ODV interview responses.
column41:
Interview Intelligence features:
•Transcripts of candidate responses (verbatim voice-to-text transcription)
•Summaries of candidate responses
o	Improve evaluator efficiency
o	Bring focus to the job-related aspects of a candidate’s responses
•Callouts for skill and competency-related elements
o	Highlights the most important aspects of a candidate’s responses
•Competency score explanations (for AI-scored questions)
o	Explanation of AIS competency scores helps evaluators translate  candidate responses to proficiency levels
column42: Summary of candidate responses, call out for skills and competencies.

Given the scalability limitations of Avature and the absence of viable alternatives for automated scoring, this enhancement aligns with our strategic goals for responsible AI adoption and operational efficiency in talent acquisition.

column1: AWS Neptune Database for Flight Database, SPAD dependencies
column9: implementation of Amazon Neptune, a fully managed graph database service, to support critical airline operations and Solution Product Architecture Document (SPAD) dependency management. The solution addresses two primary use cases: real-time flight rebooking during irregular operations and comprehensive SPAD dependency tracking for enterprise architecture management.
column25:
9/11/25: STR approved
Pending item: PIA
This request is to sunrise AWS Neptune Database B-1257852

The following account will need access for the testing 767397996269(svc-rcy-comp-dev)
column40:
**Irregular Operations Challenge:**
- Current flight rebooking systems lack the speed and efficiency required during irregular operations (IROPS)
- Cancelled and delayed flights create cascading impacts that are difficult to analyze with traditional relational databases
- Need for real-time path finding between cities considering multiple constraints (cost, duration, departure/arrival times)

**SPAD Dependency Management:**
- Complex interdependencies between Solution Product Architecture Documents are difficult to visualize and manage
- Impact analysis of changes to critical SPADs requires manual effort and is error-prone
- Classification-based dependency analysis (Vital, Critical, Essential) needs efficient querying capabilities
column41: Reduced complexity of current applications(mostly not-modernized).  Graph database needs are currently implemented with RDBMS and non-sql databases, which are not the optimal solution.  We expect reduction in cost as current implementation services will be reduced in favor of a Serverless model.  Performance gains are also expected in some critical application.
column42:
**Operational Efficiency:**
- Reduce flight rebooking time from minutes to seconds during IROPS
- Minimize passenger disruption through optimized alternative routing
- Improve operational cost efficiency through better resource utilization

**Architecture Management:**
- Accelerate impact analysis for SPAD changes
- Reduce risk of unidentified downstream dependencies
- Enable proactive management of critical system components
column43: Data will reside in AWS Neptune database and processed in AWS.
column44: Current implementations leverage RDBMS and no-sql databases with extensive code to achieve what a graph database can provide.
column45: Neptune is the main graph database provided by AWS as a managed service.
column47: This is an AWS managed service
column51: Being a managed service, support for the service is covered by AWS
column65: AWS Neptune graph database is an ideal solution for storing and accessing graph-based data instead of relying on RDBMS and no-sql databases.  We currently have multiple use-cases at Delta where data is organized as a graph, a set of nodes and edges: Flight data is a constantly changing graph where airport/city represents a node(origin/destination) and edges contain attributes such as duration, departure time, arrival time and more.  Finding possible paths for a given customer is the basis of IROP service recovery, a functionality Neptune natively support. Another use-case is building an enterprise repository of application dependencies.  This capability is essential during incident management.  These arguments are in favor of approving this request

column9:
This request includes both Mainframe and TechOps.

The Analysis and Renovation Catalyst (ARC) asset provides insights for modernizing Mainframe and distributed applications. It can perform static code analysis to identify the program structure, unused and unfinished code, dependencies, and extract business rules.

Additional Info:
The solution would exist entirely in an IBM controlled AWS account.   Although there is a slight depiction of Delta’s network (rightmost box) this is for context only (no changes to Delta’s environment).   We are treating this a SaaS offering from IBM.   Inputs from Delta would be SFTP of source code files.   UI access for the resulting knowledge base would be HTTPS via browser.   I believe a safe number of Delta users would be 2-5.   As stated in the STR this is a PoC.    In the event value is achieved from the PoC we might reconsider expanding the business domains and present another STR for a Delta-controlled AWS account where we would apply the rules you mentioned below as well as amber & emerald mandates as well as submit an updated AI Mandate response.

column1: KAI - Delta Vacation’s in-house AI Powered Itinerary Planner
column9:
Delta Vacations aims to revolutionize the travel planning experience by integrating an AI-powered conversational trip planning assistant into its digital ecosystem. This innovative feature leverages a custom-trained Large Language Model (LLM) fine-tuned on Delta's proprietary travel data (packages, pricing, content, policies – similar source as the AI Site Search in Delta.com) to create a natural, intuitive interface for customers to discover, customize, and book their perfect vacations. 

This initiative directly supports Delta's broader strategic pillars: 

Digital transformation by modernizing the booking experience 

Customer-centricity by reducing friction and enhancing personalization 

Competitive differentiation through innovative technology integration 

Revenue optimization by improving conversion and increasing package attachment rates 

The AI trip planner will function as a dynamic, intelligent assistant that understands natural language inputs, maintains conversational context, and guides users through the complex decision-making process of vacation planning. By responding to queries like "Plan me a beach vacation from Atlanta for a family of four in July under $3,000," the system will dramatically simplify the customer journey while creating new opportunities for upselling and cross-selling Delta's full suite of travel products.
column25:
10/7/25: STR approved
Pending item: PIA
column40:
Customer Challenges 

Complexity Overload: Travel planning involves numerous interconnected decisions (destinations, dates, accommodations, activities, transportation) that create cognitive burden and decision paralysis for customers. 

Information Fragmentation: Users currently must navigate multiple sections of the website to piece together trip components, leading to frustration and abandoned sessions. 

Personalization Gap: The current experience requires extensive manual filtering and browsing to find options that match specific preferences and constraints. 

Confidence Deficit: Customers often struggle to validate whether their selections align with their needs, potentially leading to post-booking regret. 

 
Business Challenges 

Conversion Friction: The existing multi-step booking funnel creates numerous drop-off points, with only 2.3% of sessions resulting in completed bookings. 

Limited Cross-Selling: Current package attachment rates hover at 15%, below industry benchmarks of 22-25%. 

Underutilized Inventory: Approximately 35% of available inventory fails to convert, particularly for non-peak seasons and emerging destinations. 

Support Burden: 47% of customer support calls relate to pre-booking research questions that could be handled by an intelligent assistant. 

Competitive Pressure: Major OTAs are already deploying AI assistants, threatening Delta's direct booking share. 

 
The AI-powered trip planning experience addresses these challenges by providing a unified, conversational interface that simplifies decision-making, delivers personalized recommendations, and creates a more engaging, confidence-building booking journey.
column41:
Core benefit: Replace Delta Vacation’s fragmented 7-page booking flow with a single, AI-driven conversational surface that dramatically lowers cognitive load and decision friction — speeding time-to-decision, raising conversion and attach rates, and creating a more personalized, loyalty-building experience. 
 
CX Improvement:  

Fewer steps, less friction: Users move from clicking through seven separate pages (search → options → extras → seats → payment, etc.) to a single multi-turn conversation that surfaces only what matters, when it matters. 

Preserved context & memory: Multi-turn chat keeps prior answers in context (dates, budget, preferences), so customers aren’t forced to re-enter info across pages. 

Guided decisioning vs choice overload: The assistant synthesizes options and explains tradeoffs (price vs. convenience) — preventing paralysis that causes abandonment in long multi-page funnels. 

Faster, mobile-native interaction: Conversational flow maps naturally to mobile screens (reducing form fatigue and page loads), improving completion on mobile where multi-page funnels lose users. 

Real-time personalization & prefill: SkyMiles/profile data and CDP signals auto-prefill relevant defaults (class, loyalty upgrades), reducing manual steps and increasing trust. 

Easy modifications & reversibility: Instead of re-navigating pages to edit a booking, users ask a simple request (“add snorkeling, remove spa”) and get an immediate, contextual update. 

 
Direct business impact (linked to KPIs) 

Higher conversions: Removing multi-page drop-offs and simplifying the path supports the targeted +30% uplift in conversion. 

Shorter sessions → faster decisions: Replacing page-hops with chat helps achieve the −20 to −30% session duration reduction target (quicker path to purchase). 

Greater attach & AOV: Contextual, in-flow upsells increase package/ancillary attach rates (+27–53%) and Average Booking Value (+10–20%). 

Lower support & operational costs: Self-service in the conversation reduces pre-booking calls (−20 to −40%), lowering contact center spend. 

Stronger brand & retention: A simpler, more human planning experience drives NPS gains (+6 to +13), feeding higher repeat purchase/LTV. 

Customer outcomes (short) 

Faster planning, less frustration, clearer choices. 

Perceived personalization and trust through prefilled preferences and transparent rationale. 

One coherent journey from inspiration → itinerary → booking (shareable and modifiable).
column42:
onversational Trip Planning

Continuous model improvement via usage data

Current commercial initiatives use incomplete testing methodologies – generally testing pre/post periods against comparison cities that do not account for noise and causality. Causalens methodologies allows the business to quantify direct cause/effect relationship and to improve the speed of testing new pricing strategies. 
This testing also benefits the commercial organization in two ways:  
Speed: Traditional counterfactual testing takes time, CausaLens platform supports faster development of models 
Skillset: Current gap exists within commercial organization regarding causal inference skillset; CausaLens allows for all data scientists to create their own experiments and measure cause/effect relationships

column84: Vendor enageent to comply with our SaaS mandate: S1 End-to-End Encryption - All data in transit and at rest must be encrypted, in compliance with our policies. This applies to data within the SaaS platform, and the integration or access to Delta systems. < Please specify how data will be encrypted on your end, at rest and in transit> All access to all applications on causaLens platform is end-to-end encrypted with HTTPS. Any access to your S3 bucket is also encrypted via HTTPS. We do not intend to store any other data at rest. S2.A: All Delta users must be authenticated by Global Auth, including MFA if required by Delta security standards. This requires a federated authentication integration with the SaaS provider. < Please state that any of the UI applications you provide will be integrated with Delta Global Identity > Yes we will integrate our authentication gateway (login.causalens.com) with your IDP such that all Delta users will be using Delta's IDP and Delta's MFA policies. S4 Logging - The SaaS provider must offer logging or a way to view events for important transactions (e.g. logins, high-value transactions, administrative changes, etc.) < Please state how observability will be available to Delta > Platform already offers the ability to view logs of all applications running on it, including a UI log browser. S5 Restrict Network Access - The Delta tenant of the SaaS solution must only be accessible from the Delta network unless there is a business requirement to allow access from the public Internet. < Please state what network guidelines are in place so that only Delta CIDRs are allowed > Being a multitenanted platform, this is not easily possible given that it would necessitate dedicated infrastructure to support. In this case I would suggest a requirement for causaLens and Delta staff to work on the data together as a sufficient requirement to waive this condition. - the cloud platform operates upon K8S: instances of tenant's applications, or research tools such as jupyter notebook are separate instances launched on the same k8s cluster - instances for different customers (and within customers, different "workspaces" as we call them) are placed into a separate kubernetes namespaces, and therefore achieve a network boundary between them too. That means that instances from 2 different customers will always be in different namespaces and have a network boundary. - the instances running on k8s mount a cluster-wide elastic file system (NFS) but are limited to mounting different directories (called file stores on our platform). The association of file stores <-> customer workspaces is made through logical association on basis of customer-file store permission tables - each instance runs an HTTPS endpoint and is gated with SSO and controls who has access to the instance on the basis of a group claim in OIDC - each user is assigned to groups. Typically customers have their own group, or customer may map to multiple groups when dealing with multiple projects across an organization. But it is never the case that a single group is shared between two customers
column85: - underlying LLM infrastructure (the models) is shared, but runs in inference mode only (see below) - No, we strictly do no training upon customer data, nor make it available to anyone - LLMs run in purely inference mode, that means that their weights are not being updated by the requests that pass through a common gateway. Inference mode means that LLM models are immutable / static, they do not learn/update as they see more data.

column9: External Attack Surface Management (EASM) is the continuous process of discovering, inventorying, and assessing an organization's internet-facing digital assets, including cloud services, web applications, and domains, to identify and mitigate vulnerabilities attackers could exploit. It provides a view of the organization's external digital footprint as seen by an attacker, helping to uncover "unknown unknowns" like shadow IT and misconfigurations to proactively reduce security risks and strengthen cyber resilience.

column51:
1.	Availability. AirBadge will make the Services available 99.8% of the time. Availability will be calculated over the previous 90 days, on a rolling basis, as follows:

(total – (downtime + excluded)/total * 100) ≥ 99.8

2.	Definitions.

“Service” means the latest production version of the online services made available by AirBadge
“Total” means the total number of minutes over the previous 90 days, on a rolling basis
“Downtime” means minutes during which the Services are not available
“Excluded” means any downtime caused by planned downtime of which AirBadge provides the notice stated in Section 3 below, or force majeure events, which for purposes of this Exhibit means circumstances beyond AirBadge’s reasonable control
3.	Planned Maintenance. AirBadge will provide advance notice of any planned downtime, and will schedule planned downtime outside of standard business hours (9 a.m. to 5 p.m. U.S. Central time, excluding holidays) or during such other hours where this is reasonably designed to minimize the impact on users. AirBadge will use commercially reasonable efforts to provide at least 48 hours’ advance notice.

4.	Reporting. AirBadge will provide Customer with access to statistics on Service availability over the previous 90 days, on a rolling basis, upon request but no more than once per 60-day period.

5.	Support Contacts. AirBadge Support can be contacted via support ticket in the AirBadge application. AirBadge will provide Customer support weekdays 9:00 am to 5:00 pm US Central Time (excluding holidays). AirBadge will use reasonable efforts to respond to all email inquiries within one (1) business day. Support tickets are triaged based on the urgency of the inquiry. If reporting an urgent matter or critical issue, please make this clear in the email to the Support team

6.	Remedies. In the event the uptime availability is not met during any calendar month during the Term, Customer will be entitled to credits against its subsequent payment obligations (as set forth in the Agreement) according to the following table:
Service Availability
	Credit as a Percentage of Monthly Billing

Less than 99.8% and equal or higher than 99%	10% of the Fees payable in respect of the month in which such Uptime Availability is not met

Less than 99% and equal or higher than 95%	25% of the Fees payable in respect of the month in which such Uptime Availability is not met

Less than 95 to .0%
	50% of the Fees payable in respect of the month in which such Uptime Availability is not met


7.	Service Level Termination Right.  Customer may terminate this Agreement upon written notice to AirBadge and without liability for the Service Fees remaining in the Initial Term, or Renewal Term, as applicable, in the event that a Service Credit is due Customer in any three (3) consecutive months or in any five (5) or more months during the Initial Term, or Renewal Term, as applicable.
