column9:
Technology Solution Overview:

Delta Air Lines proposes to implement a proof of concept integration with Palantir Foundry, a data analytics and decision support platform, to address critical operational visibility gaps in crew change management during irregular operations (IROPs).

Technical Architecture: The solution involves deploying Palantir Foundry connectors within Delta's AWS environment to establish secure, direct data feeds from five internal IT systems: Crew Management (Crew IT), Flight Operations, TechOps (aircraft maintenance), Airport Customer Services (ACS), and external airport curfew databases. Data flows through encrypted channels without intermediate storage in Delta AWS, connecting directly to Palantir's cloud-hosted analytics platform.

Functional Capabilities: The system will analyze real-time operational data to predict cascading effects of crew reassignments on subsequent flight operations. It will classify crew changes as "good breaks" (minimal downstream impact) or "bad breaks" (significant cascading disruptions), enabling Operations Control Center personnel to make informed decisions during irregular operations and minimize network-wide disruptions.

Technology Stack:

Palantir Foundry (SaaS analytics platform)
AWS-hosted integration layer with IAM, encryption, and audit controls
Direct API integrations with existing Delta IT systems
Real-time data processing and machine learning analytics
Web-based dashboard interface for OCC operators
Security Controls: End-to-end encryption, role-based access controls, comprehensive audit logging, and secure VPN connectivity between Delta AWS and Palantir infrastructure. All data transmission occurs over encrypted channels with no persistent storage in intermediate systems.

Scope Limitations: Proof of concept is restricted to crew change impact analysis only, with no expansion to other operational domains without separate review and approval.
column25: VRA update Steve McNamara:With this 3-month POC and Palantir Technologies being up to date on their Vendor Risk Assessments, additional assessment was not required from the Vendor Risk Management side. The last Vendor Risk Assessment done for Palantir was in 2024 and no security findings were found based on the completed Due Diligence Questionnaire. I did update the POC engagement with the updated information regarding connectors and data. If you decide to move forward with the POC, you will need to complete another Engagement for the Production implementation.
column40:
Business Justification and Technical Need:

Business Drivers: Delta's Operations Control Center (OCC) currently operates with a critical blind spot during irregular operations (IROPs) - the inability to assess cascading impacts of crew reassignments on downstream flight operations. This gap forces operational decisions to be made reactively rather than proactively, often resulting in:

Unintended cascading delays that compound throughout the network
Increased customer disruption and compensation costs
Suboptimal resource utilization during recovery operations
Extended recovery times from irregular operations
Reduced operational efficiency and on-time performance metrics
Technical Limitations of Current State: Our existing systems operate in silos, lacking the integrated analytical capability to model complex interdependencies between crew assignments, aircraft positioning, gate availability, airport constraints, and maintenance requirements. Current crew management tools can identify available crew but cannot predict the operational ripple effects of reassignment decisions across the network.

Strategic Business Value: Implementing predictive crew change impact analysis will enable:

Proactive IROP management with data-driven decision making
Reduced network disruption through "good break" identification
Improved customer experience through minimized cascading delays
Enhanced operational resilience and faster recovery times
Competitive advantage in operational reliability metrics
Technical Requirements: The solution requires real-time integration of disparate operational data sources with advanced analytics capabilities that exceed our current internal technical capacity. Palantir Foundry provides the necessary machine learning algorithms, data integration platform, and analytical processing power to deliver actionable insights within the time-critical decision windows required during irregular operations.

Risk Mitigation: Without this capability, Delta continues to operate with reactive crew management during IROPs, increasing the risk of network-wide disruptions that impact thousands of passengers and generate significant operational costs.
column41:
Business Benefits and Return on Investment:

Quantifiable Cost Savings:

Reduced Passenger Compensation: Minimizing cascading delays decreases denied boarding compensation, meal vouchers, and hotel accommodations. Estimated savings of $2-5M annually based on 15-25% reduction in IROP-related passenger disruptions.
Crew Overtime Reduction: Better crew positioning reduces premium pay for out-of-position crews and last-minute crew scheduling. Projected savings of $1-3M annually through optimized crew utilization.
Aircraft Repositioning Costs: Preventing "bad breaks" reduces need for costly aircraft ferrying and repositioning flights. Estimated $500K-1.5M annual savings.
Operational Recovery Time: Faster IROP recovery reduces extended operational costs including ground handling, gate fees, and fuel inefficiencies. Projected $1-2M annual savings.
Revenue Protection:

Customer Retention: Improved operational reliability protects revenue from customer defection due to poor service experience. Estimated $5-10M annual revenue protection.
Premium Pricing Maintenance: Operational excellence supports Delta's premium positioning and pricing power in the market.
Operational Efficiency Gains:

OCC Productivity: Reduced decision-making time and improved accuracy enables OCC staff to handle higher volumes of irregular operations with existing headcount.
Network Resilience: Enhanced ability to contain disruptions prevents system-wide impacts that historically require days to fully recover.
Strategic Value:

Competitive Differentiation: Superior operational reliability during weather events and system disruptions provides measurable competitive advantage.
Scalability: Analytics platform provides foundation for expanding predictive capabilities to other operational domains.
Investment and ROI:

Proof of Concept Cost: $0 (provided at no cost by Palantir)
Internal Resource Investment: Minimal - leveraging existing IT infrastructure and personnel
Total Estimated Annual Benefit: $10-22M in combined cost savings and revenue protection
ROI: Immediate positive return with no upfront capital investment required for proof of concept
Risk Mitigation Value: Prevents potential multi-million dollar operational meltdowns during major weather events or system failures that historically cost $20-50M in recovery expenses and customer compensation.
column42:
Core Business Capabilities:

1. Cascading Impact Analysis

Real-time assessment of how crew reassignments affect downstream flight operations
Predictive modeling of network-wide disruption propagation
Quantification of potential delay minutes across affected flights
2. Decision Classification System

Automated categorization of crew changes as "good breaks" vs "bad breaks"
Risk scoring for each potential crew reassignment option
Comparative analysis of multiple crew change scenarios
3. Operational Constraint Integration

Incorporation of airport curfew restrictions into decision modeling
Gate availability and ground handling capacity considerations
Aircraft maintenance window and positioning requirements
Crew duty time and regulatory compliance validation
4. Real-Time Decision Support

Interactive dashboard for Operations Control Center personnel
What-if scenario modeling for crew reassignment options
Prioritized recommendations based on network impact minimization
Time-sensitive alerts for critical decision windows
5. Network Optimization

Identification of optimal crew positioning to minimize future disruption risk
Proactive crew scheduling recommendations during normal operations
Strategic crew base utilization insights for long-term planning
6. Performance Analytics

Historical analysis of crew change decisions and their actual outcomes
Continuous learning and model improvement based on operational results
Benchmarking and trend analysis for operational performance metrics
7. Cross-Functional Data Integration

Unified view of crew, aircraft, gate, and operational constraint data
Elimination of information silos between operational departments
Single source of truth for complex operational decision-making
8. Regulatory Compliance Monitoring

Automated validation of crew duty time regulations
Flight time limitation compliance checking
Regulatory reporting and audit trail capabilities
These capabilities collectively enable proactive, data-driven crew management during irregular operations, transforming reactive crisis management into strategic operational optimization.
column43:
Data Storage and Processing Locations:

Primary Data Storage:

Delta Internal Systems: All source data remains in existing Delta-owned data centers and systems within the United States
No Intermediate Storage: No data persistence occurs within Delta's AWS integration layer - data flows through connectors without storage
Processing Locations:

Palantir Infrastructure: Data processing occurs within Palantir's cloud infrastructure hosted in United States-based data centers
Geographic Boundaries: All data processing remains within US borders in compliance with Delta's data residency requirements
Cloud Provider: Palantir utilizes AWS infrastructure for their Foundry platform, with data centers located in US regions
Data Movement:

Transit Path: Data flows directly from Delta internal systems → Delta AWS connectors → Palantir US data centers
No International Transfer: No data crosses international boundaries during processing or storage
Encryption in Transit: All data movement occurs over encrypted channels (TLS 1.2+)
Temporary Processing:

In-Memory Processing: Palantir processes data in-memory for real-time analytics without persistent storage of raw operational data
Analytical Results: Only aggregated insights and model outputs are retained, not underlying personal or operational data
Data Retention: Specific retention periods to be defined in data processing agreement with Palantir
Compliance Considerations:

US Data Residency: All data storage and processing occurs within United States jurisdiction
GDPR Considerations: While crew data may include EU nationals, processing occurs within established legal frameworks
Regulatory Alignment: Data residency aligns with aviation industry regulatory requirements and Delta's data governance policies
Backup and Recovery:

Palantir Backups: Any backup data maintained by Palantir remains within US-based infrastructure
Delta Control: Delta retains full control over source data in internal systems regardless of Palantir processing
column44:
Comparable Alternative Solutions:

AWS Native Solutions (Already Approved at Delta):

Amazon SageMaker: Machine learning platform for predictive analytics and model development
AWS Glue: Data integration and ETL service for connecting disparate data sources
Amazon QuickSight: Business intelligence and visualization platform
AWS Lambda + Step Functions: Serverless computing for real-time data processing
Amazon Kinesis: Real-time data streaming and analytics
Amazon Redshift: Data warehousing for analytical workloads
Honest Technical Comparison:

AWS Native Capabilities:

Strategic Alignment: Fully aligns with Delta's AWS-first strategy and existing vendor relationship
Governance Advantage: Leverages Delta's mature AWS governance framework, security controls, and operational procedures
Architectural Consistency: Maintains single-vendor cloud strategy without introducing additional complexity
Mainframe Integration: Can leverage existing AWS-to-mainframe integration patterns already established at Delta
Weaknesses: Requires significant development effort, no pre-built operational analytics models, longer time-to-market
Palantir Architectural Impact Assessment:

Mainframe Modernization Considerations:

Adds Complexity: Introduces another layer on top of existing Mainframe/TPF → AWS → Palantir architecture, further complicating the technology stack
Data Duplication Risk: Creates potential for additional data copies and synchronization challenges beyond existing AWS layers
Integration Burden: Requires maintaining integration points with both mainframe systems and AWS layers, increasing technical debt
Modernization Impediment: May reduce incentive to modernize core mainframe systems by providing workaround solutions
Shadow IT and Governance Risks:

Primary Users: Data Science teams and business shadow IT groups who typically operate outside formal IT governance
Governance Gap: Palantir's self-service capabilities may enable uncontrolled proliferation of analytics solutions
Security Exposure: Business teams may create unsecured data pipelines or analytics without proper oversight
Compliance Risk: Shadow IT usage could lead to data handling violations or regulatory non-compliance
Fragmentation: May accelerate the existing problem of duplicated systems with overlapping capabilities
Strategic Architecture Concerns:

System Proliferation: Adds to Delta's existing challenge of managing overlapping capabilities across multiple platforms
Technical Debt: Creates additional integration and maintenance burden on already complex mainframe-centric architecture
Vendor Sprawl: Introduces new vendor relationship requiring separate governance, security, and operational procedures
Honest Business Assessment: While Palantir offers faster time-to-value, it exacerbates Delta's core architectural challenges:

Delays mainframe modernization by providing another workaround layer
Enables shadow IT proliferation that Delta is actively trying to contain
Adds to system duplication problems rather than consolidating capabilities
Recommendation Rationale: The free POC provides requirements validation, but production implementation should prioritize AWS-native solutions that:

Support mainframe modernization strategy rather than circumventing it
Maintain centralized IT governance and security controls
Reduce rather than increase system proliferation and technical debt
Strategic Consideration: Success with Palantir POC should trigger AWS-native development that addresses the same business need while supporting Delta's broader architectural modernization goals.
column45:
Alternative Approaches if Request is Denied:

Option 1: AWS-Native Development (Recommended)

Approach: Build equivalent capabilities using approved AWS services (SageMaker, Glue, QuickSight, Lambda)
Timeline: 12-18 months development cycle
Investment: $3-7M development cost plus ongoing maintenance
Benefits: Aligns with Delta's AWS strategy, maintains governance controls, supports mainframe modernization
Risks: Longer time-to-value, uncertain outcome, requires specialized talent acquisition
Option 2: Enhanced Manual Processes

Approach: Improve existing OCC procedures with better data visualization and manual analysis tools
Timeline: 3-6 months implementation
Investment: $200K-500K for dashboard development and training
Benefits: Low cost, maintains current governance, no new vendor relationships
Limitations: Does not solve core predictive analytics need, relies on human judgment, limited scalability
Option 3: Existing System Enhancement

Approach: Extend current crew management and flight operations systems with basic impact analysis
Timeline: 6-12 months development
Investment: $1-3M system modifications
Benefits: Leverages existing systems, maintains data governance
Limitations: Limited by legacy system constraints, may not achieve desired analytical sophistication
Option 4: Delayed Implementation

Approach: Postpone initiative until mainframe modernization progresses further
Timeline: 2-3 years delay pending broader IT transformation
Investment: Deferred costs but continued operational inefficiencies
Impact: Continued exposure to cascading IROP disruptions, estimated $10-22M annual opportunity cost
Option 5: Alternative Vendor Evaluation

Approach: Evaluate other analytics platforms that better align with Delta's AWS strategy (Databricks on AWS, Snowflake)
Timeline: 6-9 months vendor selection plus 12-18 months implementation
Investment: Similar to AWS-native development
Considerations: Still introduces vendor complexity but may offer better AWS integration
Business Impact of Denial:

Operational Risk: Continued exposure to uncontrolled cascading disruptions during IROPs
Financial Impact: $10-22M annual opportunity cost from suboptimal crew change decisions
Competitive Disadvantage: Delayed operational analytics capabilities compared to industry peers
Strategic Misalignment: Forces either continued manual processes or architectural compromises
Recommended Path Forward if Denied: Proceed with Option 1 (AWS-Native Development) while implementing Option 2 (Enhanced Manual Processes) as an interim solution. This approach maintains architectural consistency, supports governance objectives, and provides immediate operational improvements while developing long-term capabilities.

Resource Requirements for Alternatives:

Data science team expansion (3-5 FTEs)
AWS solution architecture expertise
Change management for OCC operational procedures
Enhanced training programs for operational staff

Privacy Impact Assessment Implementation: $15K-20K (data governance controls, audit logging)
Compliance Validation: $20K-30K (regulatory review, documentation, approval processes)
Project Management and Coordination:

Cross-Domain Program Management: $60K-80K (6-9 month timeline, multiple IT domain coordination)
Change Management: $30K-40K (OCC training, process documentation, user adoption)
Testing and Validation: $40K-60K (end-to-end testing, user acceptance testing, performance validation)
Technical Resources:

Delta IT Engineering: $120K-180K (dedicated resources across multiple domains for 6-9 months)
AWS Solutions Architecture: $25K-35K (specialized AWS integration expertise)
Data Engineering: $80K-120K (data pipeline development, transformation logic)
Vendor Coordination:

Palantir Professional Services: $50K-75K (implementation support, configuration, training)
Third-Party Integration Support: $20K-30K (external data source connections)
Risk Mitigation and Contingency:

Integration Complexity Buffer: $75K-100K (15-20% contingency for cross-domain challenges)
Extended Timeline Risk: $50K-75K (potential delays due to mainframe integration complexity)
Total Estimated One-Time Costs: 
640K−1.0M

Cost Breakdown by Phase:

Phase 1 - Infrastructure Setup: $95K-145K (2-3 months)
Phase 2 - Data Integration: $150K-225K (4-6 months)
Phase 3 - Testing & Deployment: $90K-140K (2-3 months)
Phase 4 - Training & Go-Live: $70K-100K (1-2 months)
Contingency & Risk Buffer: $125K-175K
Timeline Impact on Costs: Given the cross-domain complexity (5x TechOps single-domain effort), realistic timeline is 8-12 months total implementation, with costs scaling proportionally due to extended resource commitment and coordination overhead.

Note: These costs assume Palantir software licensing remains free during POC period. Production licensing costs would be additional ongoing operational expenses.
column65:
Architect Analysis & Recommendations

Prepared by: Manonmani, Chellakumar Mark Robinson (Robin), IT Portfolio Architect, Delta Air Lines

Executive Summary: This POC request emerges from business-driven conversations between Delta IT and OCC teams who engaged directly with Palantir. During these discussions, Palantir positioned their platform as uniquely capable of solving Delta's data silos challenges, citing the 2024 CrowdStrike outage that disrupted Delta operations for five days as an example of problems their platform could have mitigated.

Technical Assessment: From an architectural perspective, the selected crew change impact analysis use case represents a well-defined operational analytics problem that falls within the capabilities of Delta's existing AWS ecosystem. The use case does not leverage Palantir's acclaimed Ontology framework—often cited as their differentiating technology—to its full potential, suggesting the problem scope may not require Palantir's specialized capabilities.

Alternative Solution Viability: A thorough comparative analysis indicates that AWS-native services (SageMaker, Glue, QuickSight, Lambda) could theoretically deliver equivalent functionality. However, this would require significant development investment, specialized talent acquisition, and 12-18 months of development time that Delta IT currently lacks the bandwidth to pursue.

Strategic Considerations: While the technical merits favor an AWS-native approach for long-term architectural consistency, several business factors support proceeding with the Palantir POC:

Risk Mitigation: The estimated $10-22M annual cost of operational inefficiencies justifies rapid solution deployment
Resource Constraints: Delta IT's current capacity limitations make immediate internal development impractical
Executive Alignment: Strong executive sponsorship provides necessary organizational support for rapid implementation
Validation Opportunity: The free POC serves as valuable requirements gathering for future AWS-native development
Recommendation: Approve the Palantir POC with the explicit understanding that success should trigger immediate evaluation of AWS-native alternatives for production implementation. This approach provides immediate business value while maintaining Delta's strategic architectural direction and allows proper validation of Palantir's claims regarding data integration capabilities.

Risk Mitigation: Establish clear POC success criteria and exit strategy to prevent vendor lock-in while capturing maximum learning value for future internal development efforts.

Request to evaluate three product vendors to identify a solution that meets the requirements of our proof of concept (POC).
External Attack Surface Management (EASM) is the continuous process of discovering, inventorying, and assessing an organization's internet-facing digital assets, including cloud services, web applications, and domains, to identify and mitigate vulnerabilities attackers could exploit. It provides a view of the organization's external digital footprint as seen by an attacker, helping to uncover "unknown unknowns" like shadow IT and misconfigurations to proactively reduce security risks and strengthen cyber resilience.

column9: PyPDF2 is a free and open-source pure-python PDF library capable of splitting, merging, cropping, and transforming the pages of PDF files.
column40:
When Cabin Discrepancy Reports submitted by Flight Attendants aren’t addressed by pilots before the end of flight, the MyCabin application, which is a native IOS app, attempts to create a log in the TechOps mainframe system - SCEPTRE. If this fails due to a system outage, the MyCabin Ground Server sends a fallback email 12 minutes after block-in (IN+12) to key support teams.

This fallback is currently a manual business continuity process, requiring human effort to extract defect data from PDF attachments and take action. This introduces delays, risks of error, and scalability issues.

We are working on automating this process using the open-source Python library - PyPDF2 - to extract defect data from the PDFs and trigger appropriate actions. This will:
- Ensure continuity during outages and 
- Reduce manual workload for support teams.
This automation strengthens operational resilience and aligns with our goals for reliability and streamlined support.
column41: Automating the fallback Cabin Discrepancy reporting process improves operational resilience, reduces manual workload, and ensures timely, accurate handling of cabin discrepancy issues during system outages.
column42:
PyPDF2 is a Python library designed for working with PDF files. Key capabilities relevant to automating the MyCabin fallback process include:

- PDF Parsing: Extracts text, metadata, and structure from PDF documents.
- Text Extraction: Retrieves structured or unstructured text for downstream processing.
- PDF Merging/Splitting: Combines or separates PDFs if needed for reporting or archiving.

column9: The monday.com software product is a Work Operating System (Work OS) that enables teams to build, run, and scale workflows and projects with ease. monday.com is a cloud-based platform designed to help teams manage tasks, projects, and workflows in a highly customizable and collaborative environment. It provides visual tools and automation to streamline work across departments.

column40:
Monday.com is in production and never went through the governance process. The team is seeking an incremental change to integrate Outlook to the platform. The platform is not integrated with any other applications or systems currently.
Monday.com is a cloud-based Work Operating System (Work OS) designed to help organizations centralize and streamline their work management processes. It addresses key business needs such as improving visibility, accountability, and collaboration across teams, while supporting scalability and remote work. By offering customizable workflows, real-time dashboards, and automation tools, it enables faster decision-making and reduces reliance on fragmented systems. Technically, Monday.com stands out with its no-code/low-code interface, robust integration capabilities, and developer-friendly tools like APIs and webhooks. It also meets enterprise-grade security and compliance standards, making it suitable for businesses of all sizes and industries. Overall, Monday.com empowers teams to work more efficiently, adapt quickly, and maintain alignment across complex projects and operations. 
​​The integration of monday.com with Outlook will significantly enhance Delta Air Lines' operational efficiency by streamlining communication and automating workflows. It allows emails and calendar events to be seamlessly converted into actionable tasks within monday.com, improving task tracking, cross-department collaboration, and response times. This leads to better coordination, reduced manual work, and improved service delivery across the organization.​
column41:
Monday.com can integrate with other systems like Outlook, Teams, Zendesk, Gitlab, etc. None of those integrations are currently in use. Integrating Monday.com with Outlook streamlines communication and project management by bridging the gap between email and workflow automation. This integration enables users to convert emails into actionable tasks, sync calendars for real-time scheduling, and maintain seamless collaboration without switching platforms. By centralizing updates and reducing manual data entry, teams can boost productivity, enhance transparency, and ensure that critical information never falls through the cracks.
​​The integration of monday.com with Outlook can significantly enhance Delta Air Lines' operational efficiency by streamlining communication and automating workflows.
column42: Monday.com offers a comprehensive suite of business capabilities that support efficient work management and cross-functional collaboration. It enables teams to manage projects and tasks through customizable workflows, timelines, and dependencies, while automating repetitive actions like status updates and approvals to save time and reduce errors. The platform enhances communication by centralizing discussions, file sharing, and updates within tasks, eliminating the need for scattered tools. It also supports resource and capacity planning by providing visibility into team workloads, helping managers allocate resources effectively. With built-in dashboards and reporting tools, businesses can visualize key metrics and make data-driven decisions. Monday.com extends its functionality to CRM and sales pipeline management, time tracking, document management, and even custom app development through its open API and integration capabilities. These features make it a versatile solution for aligning departments, improving productivity, and scaling operations across the organization.
column43: ​​Monday.com stores and processes customer data using the Vendor Hosted Cloud Amazon Web Services (AWS) infrastructure, with data centers located in multiple global regions to support performance, compliance, and data residency requirements. By default, most customer data is hosted in the United States, specifically in the AWS Northern Virginia region. However, Monday.com also offers data residency options in the European Union for enterprise customers and for certain users who signed up after January 2023, ensuring compliance with regulations like the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Some accounts in the Asia-Pacific region may also be hosted locally, although Japanese accounts are typically hosted in the U.S. All data is encrypted both in transit and at rest, and Monday.com adheres to strict security standards, including SOC 2 Type II, ISO/IEC 27001, and HIPAA. This infrastructure ensures that customer data is handled securely and in accordance with regional compliance requirements.​
column44: Monday.com has several comparable alternatives that organizations like Delta Air Lines may already use or have approved. Tools such as Microsoft Project and Microsoft Planner are commonly adopted in enterprise environments due to their deep integration with Microsoft 365 and robust project planning features. Smartsheet is another strong alternative, offering a spreadsheet-like interface with powerful automation and reporting capabilities, often favored for its flexibility and compliance readiness. Asana and ClickUp provide intuitive task and workflow management, while Wrike excels in project portfolio management and resource planning. Other options like Airtable and Trello offer more lightweight, visual approaches to task tracking, and Notion combines documentation with task management for knowledge-centric teams. For enterprise-grade needs, Adobe Workfront and ServiceNow are often used for managing complex workflows, particularly in marketing, IT, and operations. These tools offer varying levels of customization, scalability, and integration, making them viable alternatives depending on the specific needs and existing infrastructure of the organization.

column9:
The Sprih Tool is a SaaS-based solution that automates and enhances emissions reporting across Scopes 1, 2, and 3, aligning with global sustainability standards. It consolidates data from multiple sources into a single, secure platform, reducing manual effort and improving accuracy.

Scope 1: Direct emissions from Delta’s operations (e.g., fuel combustion in aircraft and ground equipment).
Scope 2: Indirect emissions from purchased energy (e.g., electricity from utilities using fossil fuels).
Scope 3: All other indirect emissions, primarily from the supply chain (e.g., goods and services purchased). Suppliers’ Scope 1 and 2 emissions roll up into Delta’s Scope 3 category.

Current Challenge: Delta currently reports all three scopes annually in its ESG report. While Scopes 1 and 2 are managed by Sustainability and Fuel/SAF teams, Scope 3 reporting is manual and resource-intensive, requiring vendor spend categorization, manual application of EPA emission factors, and maintenance of a custom dashboard.

By automating emissions reporting and providing actionable insights, the Sprih Tool:
-Reduces manual workload and operational risk.
-Improves data quality and completeness.
-Strengthens Delta’s ability to meet sustainability goals and regulatory requirements.
-Positions Delta to lead in supplier engagement and climate risk mitigation.
column25:
10/15/25: STR approved

column40: Delta must monitor and report supply chain emissions to meet regulatory, ESG, and internal sustainability requirements. Today, this process is fragmented and highly manual, relying on multiple teams and disparate data sources. The new tool addresses these challenges by automating data collection from publicly available supplier reports, applying standardized calculations, and engaging suppliers only when additional details are required. This streamlined approach improves data accuracy, reduces operational effort, and ensures timely, audit-ready reporting—making it a critical component of Delta’s supply chain sustainability strategy.
column41:
Sprih streamlines and strengthens Delta’s supply chain emissions reporting by automating data collection and improving accuracy—particularly for Scope 3 emissions, which are the most complex to measure.
(Scope 3: All other indirect emissions, primarily from the supply chain (e.g., goods and services purchased). Suppliers’ Scope 1 and 2 emissions roll up into Delta’s Scope 3 category)
-Efficiency: Eliminates manual data gathering by automatically pulling supplier-specific metrics from ESG reports and applying spend-based methodology for others.
Comprehensive Coverage: Delivers full Scope 3 visibility across top ~300 vendors and beyond.
-Data Quality & Audit Readiness: Enhances accuracy and includes third-party verification for compliance confidence.
-Secure & Integrated: Uses SSO for secure access and ensures spend data is uploaded through the Sprih platform, not email.
-Strategic Impact: Provides actionable insights to engage suppliers on sustainability, reduce climate risk, and support Delta’s environmental commitments.
column42:
This SaaS-based solution provides a comprehensive platform for emissions measurement and sustainability insights, designed to align with global reporting standards.
Core Capabilities:

-End-to-End Emissions Calculation: Accurately calculates emissions across Scopes 1, 2, and 3, including complex supply chain emissions, using globally recognized methodologies.
-Automated Data Integration: Pulls supplier-specific ESG metrics for top vendors and applies spend-based methodology for others, ensuring full Scope 3 coverage without manual effort. (Scope 3: All other indirect emissions, primarily from the supply chain (e.g., goods and services purchased). Suppliers’ Scope 1 and 2 emissions roll up into Delta’s Scope 3 category.)
-Actionable Sustainability Insights: Identifies emissions hotspots, highlights reduction opportunities, and supports stronger supplier engagement strategies.
-Audit-Ready Compliance: Includes third-party verification to ensure accuracy and readiness for audits and ESG reporting.
-Secure & Scalable: Cloud-based, SSO-enabled platform with secure data upload for sensitive spend information.

-Business Impact: By automating emissions reporting and providing actionable insights, this solution reduces manual workload, improves data quality, and strengthens Delta’s ability to meet sustainability goals while mitigating climate risk.

column51:
1. System Availability
The platform must maintain 99.5% system availability during each calendar year of the subscription term.

System Availability is defined as the percentage of total annual minutes during which the platform’s key components are operational, excluding downtime caused by:
-Scheduled maintenance (with prior notice)
-Force Majeure events
-Malicious attacks
-Issues related to the customer’s devices, networks, or ISP
-Inability to deliver service due to customer or user actions
-The vendor reserves the right to schedule maintenance with reasonable notice and may adjust maintenance windows with prior communication.

2. Support and Maintenance Services
Included in the subscription, the vendor will provide:
-Electronic Support: Assistance in identifying and resolving platform issues.
-Fixes and Error Corrections: To restore the platform to substantial conformity with documentation.
-Enhancements: Delivery of all platform improvements and updates.

3. Response and Resolution Goals
-Business Hours: 10:00 AM – 6:00 PM EST, Monday–Friday (excluding holidays).
-Response: Acknowledgment of the reported issue, including assigned engineer, timestamp, and severity level.
-Workaround: A temporary solution that allows continued use of the platform without significant impairment.

Error Severity: Critical impact to business function (e.g., function cannot be executed)
Response Goal: Within 2 business hours
Resolution Goal: Workaround or fix within 24 hours after issue is confirmed and reproducible

This SaaS platform eliminates manual processes, improves data accuracy, and ensures audit-ready compliance aligned with global sustainability standards. By consolidating supplier data and providing actionable insights, Sprih strengthens Scope 3 visibility, supports regulatory compliance, and advances Delta’s sustainability commitments efficiently and securely. At an annual cost of $140K with no implementation fees, the solution delivers significant operational and strategic value while minimizing risk.

column9:
Aircraft Condition Monitoring System (ACMS) encoding software for Safran equipped A319 and A320 aircraft.  This software creates ACMS software for the aircraft, which then defines acquisition and data transmission standards for that aircraft. ACMS is a system within all of our aircraft that generates reports (snapshot and full flight) of aircraft sensor data, which help fuel Delta’s Predictive Maintenance, Flight Safety, etc. programs. ACMS software is DO-178C Level E aircraft software, and is user modifiable software and has no effect on the safety or operation of the aircraft. 

Tech Ops currently uses an off-network machine to develop ACMS aircraft software parts. Due to this machine getting old, we would like to bring this software to an IT-supported machine. We have procured a desktop computer (Watlcamp10857) and this product request form is to have this software installed on the new Delta-IT support workstation.
column40:

Tech Ops currently uses an off-network machine to develop and simulate ACMS aircraft software parts. Due to this machine getting old, we would like to bring this software to an IT-supported machine. column9:
Paramiko is a pure-Python [1] implementation of the SSHv2 protocol [2], providing both client and server functionality. It provides the foundation for the high-level SSH library Fabric, which is what we recommend you use for common client use-cases such as running remote shell commands or transferring files.

Direct use of Paramiko itself is only intended for users who need advanced/low-level primitives or want to run an in-Python sshd.

For installation information, changelogs, FAQs and similar, please visit our main project website; for API details, see the versioned docs. Additionally, the project maintainer keeps a roadmap on his personal site.

https://www.paramiko.org/
column25:
10/2/25: STR approved
Pending items: PIA for Crew DB Exadata
Paramiko is required to execute an Oracle Exadata@AWS command in the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI):
o	We have python code for a lambda function which will log into the Exadata box and fire the switchover/failover command.
o	The only issue is that Delta AWS does not seem to have the paramiko module installed.
o	In order to run the command, we will need paramiko, or a similar module like ssh2-python, asyncssh, parallel-ssh, etc.
No currently existing library at Delta will perform this function.
column40:
•	To date, the Lambda functions region-failover-CRMCSCDBCS & az_failover-CRMCSCDBCS have always used ssmSendCommand to execute commands on the EC2 servers.
•	However, there is no way to point ssmSendCommand at the Exadata hosts, because they are not EC2 servers. The compute nodes actually don’t even have an ARN, they only show as OCIDs in AWS.
•	Therefore, we cannot use the current Delta standard method to invoke a command on the Exadata boxes.
•	However, I have the solution to this problem:
  o	Python code for a lambda function which will log into the Exadata box and fire the switchover/failover command.
  o	The only issue is that Delta AWS does not seem to have the paramiko module installed.
  o	In order to run the command, we will need paramiko, or a similar module like ssh2-python, asyncssh, parallel-ssh, etc.

column40: Amazon Bedrock enables automated case summary generation that significantly reduces manual documentation effort while ensuring consistency across case management processes. Technically, Bedrock integrates seamlessly with the existing AWS infrastructure, including Redshift Serverless for data access. The serverless architecture provides cost-effective scaling without model hosting overhead, while automated processing of both open and closed cases maintains comprehensive, up-to-date documentation that improves case visibility and decision-making for support teams.
column41: The automated case summary system delivers measurable ROI through significant labor cost savings by eliminating manual documentation tasks that typically require 15-30 minutes per case. With processing capabilities of hundreds of cases per batch, the system can save thousands of hours annually in manual effort, translating to substantial cost reductions in operational overhead. Beyond direct labor savings, the solution improves case resolution times by providing consistent, comprehensive summaries that enable faster knowledge transfer and decision-making. The multi-model approach ensures high-quality documentation that reduces case escalations and repeat inquiries, further driving down support costs. The serverless AWS architecture minimizes infrastructure costs while providing scalable processing capacity that grows with business needs, making the solution cost-effective from both operational and technical perspectives.
column42:
The program will use Bedrock to Automatically generates comprehensive summaries for open cases and closed cases without recent documentation 

Processes cases in configurable batches with support for both individual case selection and bulk processing 

Maintains complete case history integration including initial questions, updates, and status changes 
Connects to Redshift Serverless via direct database connections  

Retrieves comprehensive case data including headers, history, categories, and service provider information 

Stores generated summaries back to the database for future reference and reporting 
 Implements intelligent business rules to identify cases requiring summaries based on status and previous summary dates 

Supports both automated bulk processing and targeted case selection capabilities 

Provides configurable batch sizes and processing parameters for optimal performance
column43: GHW AWS native cloud's Redshift warehouse.
column46: N/A
column51: N/A
column61: N/A
column65:
The proposed Amazon Bedrock implementation using Claude Sonnet via Bedrock, for automated case summary generation is a focused, pragmatic solution.
Technical Architecture Assessment
Strengths
AWS-Native Integration: Excellent leverage of existing Redshift Serverless infrastructure with direct Bedrock integration. Minimal architectural complexity with clear data flow from case retrieval to summary storage.
Focused Model Selection: Claude Sonnet provides optimal balance of quality and cost for case summarization without unnecessary multi-model complexity.
Serverless Architecture: No infrastructure management overhead, automatic scaling, and pay-per-use cost model aligns with operational efficiency goals.

Labor Cost Reduction: Eliminates 15-30 minutes of manual documentation per case
Consistency: Standardized summary format and quality across all cases
Scalability: Handles varying case volumes without operational overhead

Technical Risks (Low): Single model dependency, basic error handling

Final Recommendation
APPROVE - This is a low-risk, high-value implementation that demonstrates clear ROI while building AI capabilities. The simplified approach reduces complexity and accelerates time-to-value.

column9: External Attack Surface Management (EASM) is the continuous process of discovering, inventorying, and assessing an organization's internet-facing digital assets, including cloud services, web applications, and domains, to identify and mitigate vulnerabilities attackers could exploit. It provides a view of the organization's external digital footprint as seen by an attacker, helping to uncover "unknown unknowns" like shadow IT and misconfigurations to proactively reduce security risks and strengthen cyber resilience.
column25:
10/2/25: STR approved

column40: This product is a necessary component of a comprehensive information security program. It provides information about externally exposed risk, and helps identify complete external exposure, including unknown, unintended, forgotten, and undocumented exposures and digital footprints. These exposures can provide attackers with an unmonitored or under protected attack vector allowing for undetected or undefended exploitation.
column41: The cost of a successful exploit or compromise of Delta's environment could be extensive. Through disruption of service, compromise of customer data or exposure of confidential business information, the cost is immeasurable. This includes the loss of revenue, loss of customer trust, negative impact to brand, possible fines and penalties, restricted ability to accept certain forms of payment, legal fees, and recovery costs that include additional labor hours to restore operational status and resecure the environment.

column40:
In our current environment, Nexidia is used to tag Level 1 and Level 2 intents on customer calls, which supports volume trend analysis for forecasting and evaluating the impact of enterprise and divisional initiatives. However, the existing version requires a highly manual and time-intensive process to build new queries for identifying emerging intents or uncovering root causes. This limitation creates significant blind spots for RES and DL leadership in understanding volume drivers.
The upgrade to Topic AI Studio will immediately enhance our visibility into Level 3 intents and introduce advanced capabilities for automated intent recognition. This will dramatically reduce the manual effort required to surface new volume drivers, improve analytical agility, and enable faster, more informed decision-making. Ultimately, this upgrade will help close critical insight gaps and support more proactive and precise forecasting.
column41:
Executive Delta leadership has tasked RES with driving enterprise accountability for the volume entering RES. Identifying and remediating the root causes of this volume presents a substantial financial opportunity—potentially saving the company tens to hundreds of millions of dollars annually.
The upgraded tool provides the precision and depth needed to uncover specific volume drivers with greater fidelity. This enables the enterprise to take targeted action—whether through policy changes, process improvements, or technology enhancements—to prevent unnecessary volume from reaching RES. By equipping teams with actionable insights, this upgrade directly supports strategic cost reduction, operational efficiency, and enterprise-wide accountability.
column42:
The key capability introduced in this release is Topic AI Studio (TAS), which leverages large language models (LLMs) to automatically identify and categorize customer contact intents with greater granularity and accuracy. TAS not only surfaces Level 3 intents but also detects discrete agent actions (e.g., “Collect billing information”), enabling a deeper understanding of both customer needs and agent behavior.
This enhanced capability allows for more precise root cause analysis, accelerates the identification of emerging volume drivers, and supports targeted operational improvements. By automating what was previously a manual and time-consuming process, TAS empowers RES and enterprise teams to act faster and more effectively on insights.
column43: CTR and audio data are securely pushed to a designated S3 bucket, where the NiCE platform ingests it into their processing ecosystem. Each morning, NiCE returns processed DEU files to a Delta-owned S3 bucket, enabling seamless ingestion back into our Enterprise Data Warehouse (EDW).
column44:
While Netomi and Qualtrics offer products with some overlapping capabilities, neither company has the same deep call center expertise that NiCE possesses.
Additionally, implementing either alternative would require significant time, resources, and customization to integrate with RES systems—posing operational and financial barriers that make them impractical in our current context. In contrast, the proposed solution delivers immediate value with minimal lift.
column45:
An alternative approach would be to engage additional consulting resources from NiCE to manually perform call listening and analysis. This method would be significantly more tedious, slow, and resource-intensive—costing hundreds of thousands to potentially millions of dollars annually.
Beyond the financial burden, manual call listening lacks scalability and timeliness, making it impractical for identifying emerging volume drivers or supporting agile decision-making. In contrast, the proposed upgrade automates this process using AI, delivering faster, more accurate insights at a fraction of the cost and effort—while enabling RES to meet enterprise expectations for accountability and impact.

column84: Nexidia meets Delta’s SaaS platform requirements: • Encryption: All data in transit and at rest is encrypted in accordance with Delta’s security policies. • Authentication & Authorization: • Delta users authenticate via Global Auth with MFA support. • API credentials are securely stored, controlled, and rotated. • Role-based access is supported; AJO can be integrated with AD groups or alternative controls are in place. • CASB Integration: Integrated with Delta’s Cloud Access Security Broker. • Data Connectivity: • No direct inbound access to Delta; data flows via secure APIs/proxies. • Data access is limited to minimum required for business use. • Logging & Visibility: Provides detailed logs for campaign activity, data syncs, and user actions. • Data Residency: All data is stored and processed within U.S.-based data centers, in compliance with Delta’s residency requirements. • Network Access: Delta’s AJO tenant is restricted to approved networks or business-justified exceptions.
column85: • Information Security: Compliant with Delta’s InfoSec Policies, Standards, and Amber/Emerald mandates. • Path to Production: Follows Delta’s Path to Production deployment process. • AI Controls: AI capabilities (e.g., real-time personalization, predictive decisioning) use explainable, governed logic within Adobe’s AI framework. • Secure Architecture: Built with Zero Trust and secure-by-design principles. • Risk Alignment: AI usage aligns with Delta’s risk tolerance, with human-in-the-loop controls where required. • Threat Modeling: Covered under Adobe’s centrally managed security and threat model. • Restricted Data Protection: All models and training data are classified and protected per Delta’s “Restricted” data classification. • Monitoring & Logging: Provides visibility into AI decisioning and supports anomaly and drift detection. • Version Control & Testing: Supports versioned rule sets and AI configurations with testing for robustness and accuracy. • Auditability: AI decisions and actions are traceable for compliance and audit purposes.

column1: Enablement of AI Assistant in Stravito
column9: Stravito Assistant is a generative AI-powered insights companion designed to help users quickly and easily access, synthesize, and act on information from their company’s research library. It works through a conversational interface, enabling staff to ask questions, extract insights, automate desk research, and draft research plans—all based on proprietary company data. Assistant streamlines access to critical knowledge, democratizes insights across teams, and supports data-driven business decisions while ensuring privacy and security standards are met.

No PII Data Involved and Not leaving the Delta's network.
 
However, this request differs slightly. The business is not developing an internal solution. Stravito is a vendor’s tool, and they sought to enable AI features within its interface. Once the compliance process has been completed from our end, they will enable the AI feature for the business.

1. No it will not be exposed to customers, it's entirely internal for the business users.
2. Yes, it's an existing product - they are just adding AI/RAG functionality in their tool itself.
column40: The key business drivers are democratizing and speeding access to insights, supporting a customer-centric culture, and driving operational innovation. Technically, Assistant ensures data/contract safety, leverages Delta-specific data for better relevance, and provides differentiated, tangible value compared to external AIs.
column41: The main business benefit for Delta in using Stravito Assistant is the democratization of insights across the organization, enabling staff at every level to instantly access and act on crucial information about traveler needs, preferences, and pain points. This allows for faster, customer-centric decision making, supporting continuous improvements in business areas. By having all research and insights centralized and readily available, Delta can drive innovation, iterate on operational best practices, and ensure that business decisions are deeply informed by up-to-date customer insights.
column42:
Stravito Assistant offers Delta several specific business capabilities:
•	Conversational Insights Access: Assistant allows users to interact conversationally, making it easy for any employee to find answers within Delta’s research library, regardless of technical skill level.
•	Fast, Precise Knowledge Retrieval: The AI-powered semantic search drastically reduces the time to locate insights, providing quick, accurate, and contextually relevant responses from large volumes of data.
•	Research Plan Drafting: Assistant can help staff create research plans, supporting project scoping and planning for new studies or business questions.
•	Desk Research Automation: It performs lightweight desk research on top of Delta’s existing research reports, helping teams synthesize findings and flag knowledge gaps.
•	Smart Synthesis and Extraction: Assistant is designed to extract and synthesize key findings for strategic business decisions, ensuring that valuable research is actively used and not left “on the shelf”.
•	Customization and Security: The system customizes its responses using Delta’s proprietary data and stays aligned with data privacy and contractual boundaries, reducing legal and compliance risks.
•	Democratization of Insights: By making insights easily accessible, it supports a more data-driven, innovation-focused culture, enabling decisions that more closely align with customer needs.
column43:
Client data on Stravito Assistant is stored and processed entirely within Stravito's secure AWS production environment. Customers can choose the geographic region for their data residency. Either the United States (Ohio or N. California data centers) or the European Union (Ireland, backed up in France).
Processing within Assistant uses trusted enterprise cloud services (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud). Stravito has formal agreements to ensure that none of these providers uses or stores the client’s data for any purpose beyond fulfilling user requests. Customer content is never used to train AI models by Amazon, Microsoft, Google, or any other third party. All contract terms meet strict enterprise security and privacy requirements.

Provide an overview of the support model required ongoing.

24/7/365 User Support: Users can reach support at any time via in-app chat or email (support@stravito.com), ensuring immediate help for any issues or questions.

Standard SLA (Service Level Agreement): Clear definitions of severity levels, response, and resolution times for technical issues are provided, and these are available for Delta to review in detail.

User Feedback & Continuous Improvement: There is a built-in feedback mechanism for users to report issues or improvement ideas. Reported feedback is regularly reviewed and used to fine-tune and improve Assistant’s performance based on real-world usage.

Cloud-only Deployment & Regular Updates: Assistant is only available as a cloud-based feature, ensuring it stays up to date with improvements, patches, and the latest AI advancements. There is no on-premises option, so all updates and support are managed centrally by Stravito.

Ongoing R&D and Feature Evolution: Stravito regularly invests in improvements and new features for Assistant, informed by usage data and user interviews with power users.

InvoiceWorks (iPayables) has been in use since 2003 to enable Delta vendors to submit invoices through web entry, file upload, or SFTP. The platform supports both PO-related and non-PO-related invoices, providing web invoicing and self-service capabilities.

Currently, InvoiceWorks is undergoing the IT onboarding process due to outdated documentation. The existing materials do not clearly illustrate the integration between SAP and InvoiceWorks, and the security risk classification is incorrectly marked as “internal” instead of “confidential.”
column25:
11/19/25: STR approved
Pending items: PIA

an assessment of OnPhase on 10 Nov 2025, resulting in a “High Inherent Risk Rating”. Based on this outcome, a reassessment is not required until Nov 2027.


Earlier this year, there was an issue with the Employee file transmitted from SAP to InvoiceWorks.  The file unexpectedly restarted and was sent with only a small subset of the intended employee data.  As InvoiceWorks began processing the file, it inadvertently removed users from their system who were not included in the incoming data.  Upon noticing that thousands of records were being deleted, InvoiceWorks halted the file processing and immediately contacted Delta.
 
Delta’s Service Desk responded by opening an incident and  initiating a  bridge call. Unfortunately, due to incomplete  documentation in the Disaster Recovery Plan and Operational Guide for  InvoiceWorks—specifically regarding file integrations—it took several hours to identify the root cause: a faulty file sent from Delta.
 
As a corrective measure, it was decided that InvoiceWorks should undergo the current onboarding process to ensure data accuracy and integrity moving  forward.

column1: Harvey.AI with Word, Outlook, Sharepoint, and OneDrive Add-Ins
column9:
The Law Department is seeking an AI-powered general purpose chatbot and legal productivity solution that is purpose-built for legal professionals. While Copilot in Bing features general functionality, the legal field requires a specialized tool featuring Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) and other fine-tuning based on legal training data.  RAG is a technique which improves AI models by having them retrieve information from an external knowledge base before generating a response.
 
These tools have specialized functionality, such as: 
 
1.	General purpose conversational chatbots, like ChatGPT or Copilot in Bing, but specifically trained for the legal function; and 
2.	Legal productivity tool: perform first pass contract review (redlining) and write a brief for a litigator

Harvey.ai is a cloud-native solution hosted on Microsoft Azure and can integrate with MFA via SAML 2.0 or Oauth, supporting enterprise identity providers like Azure AD.

Also, the Law Department will be using the Harvey for Word, Harvey for Outlook, and Harvey for Sharepoint/OneDrive  Add-Ins during the pilot, for a more enriching experience.  These add-ins are available for download in the Microsoft App Store.  I have included security and data privacy information for the add-ins in the Data Residency section of this STR.

There will be approximately 15 pilot participants from the Law Department.  Also, Harvey.AI does not use MCP servers
column25: This STR is specifically for the Law Department's AI Chatbot Pilot.  If this product is selected as the final product after the pilot, another STR will be completed for this product.
column40:
The Law Department is seeking an AI-powered general purpose chatbot and legal productivity solution that is purpose-built for legal professionals. While Copilot in Bing features general functionality, the legal field requires a specialized tool featuring RAG and other fine-tuning based on legal training data. 

These tools have specialized functionality, such as:

1.	General purpose conversational chatbots, like ChatGPT or Copilot in Bing, but specifically trained for the legal function; and
2.	Legal productivity tool: perform first pass contract review (redlining) and write a brief for a litigator

To evaluate the effectiveness of CoCounsel, Harvey AI, and GC AI, Delta’s Law Department will measure success across four key dimensions: (1) task efficiency, (2) output quality<checking for correctness/completeness/grounding to sources/hallucinations through human verification of output by frequent spot-checking and confirmation during the pilot> , (3) ease of user adoption, and (4) productivity enablement. Each tool will be tested against high-impact legal workflows such as first-pass contract review, clause extraction, legal research, and litigation brief drafting. 
(1)	Efficiency will be measured by the anecdotal reduction in turnaround time for these tasks, with a target of at least 30% anecdotal improvement overline baseline. 
(2)	Output quality will be assessed through pilot participant review, with particular consideration of correctness and alignment with internal standards.
(3)	User adoption will be anecdotally tracked through usage frequency, repeat engagement, and satisfaction scores. 
(4)	Productivity enablement will focus on how well each tool supports scalable legal support, reduces manual effort, and enhances transparency in legal reasoning. 
The vendor that demonstrates the strongest alignment with legal workflows, delivers measurable efficiency gains, and earns the highest user confidence will be selected for broader implementation. This approach ensures the chosen solution not only meets technical expectations but also empowers legal teams to operate with greater agility, compliance, and innovation.
column41:
The Delta Law Department is exploring the adoption of an AI-powered cloud-based legal technology platform to enhance operational efficiency, reduce costs, and support strategic legal initiatives. These tools are designed to automate high-volume, low-complexity legal tasks—such as contract review, document drafting, and legal research—thereby freeing attorneys to focus on higher-value advisory and risk management work.

By accelerating legal workflows and minimizing manual review time, such platforms can help optimize internal legal bandwidth, reduce reliance on outside counsel, and improve turnaround times. This aligns with Delta’s broader enterprise goals of innovation, agility, and cost efficiency.

AI legal tools built for enterprise use typically deliver professional-grade outputs with minimal prompting, enabling consistent and scalable support across transactional and litigation matters. Industry benchmarks suggest that organizations implementing these solutions can achieve:

•	20–40% reduction in time spent on routine legal tasks
•	10–30% decrease in outside counsel spend
•	Faster contract cycle times and improved compliance consistency

These benefits translate into measurable ROI while also enhancing the legal department’s ability to respond quickly to business needs.

Unlike general-purpose AI tools, legal-specific platforms are designed to prioritize accuracy, traceability, and explainability, context sensitivity, and domain relevance. This is critical in minimizing the risk of “hallucinations”—instances where AI generates plausible but incorrect or misleading information—which can have serious implications in legal contexts. A tool that understands legal language, structure, and standards helps ensure that outputs are not only efficient but also reliable, reducing the risk of reputational, regulatory, or financial exposure
column42:
This solution offers two core capabilities tailored to the legal function:

•	Specialized Legal Chatbot (Use Case #1)
A domain-trained AI assistant that can interpret and respond to complex legal queries, summarize documents, extract key clauses, and assist with legal research. It enables attorneys to interact with large volumes of legal data conversationally, improving speed, accuracy, and decision-making.

•	Legal Productivity Tools (Use Case #2)
Includes advanced contract redlining and clause comparison features that automate first-pass reviews, flag deviations from standard terms, and suggest revisions. These tools significantly reduce manual effort, enhance consistency, and accelerate contract turnaround times. In addition, this use case includes rapid context-aware legal research and generates first drafts of litigation documents, memos, and correspondence, helping attorneys move faster while maintaining quality.

Together, these capabilities help legal teams work smarter and faster—reducing bottlenecks, improving quality, and enabling scalable legal support across the enterprise
column43:
The data storage location is within the MS Azure infrastructure, on the east coast. The fallback location is in Washington state.  The same is true for data processing.  All data stays in the US.  There are 3 options for data storage: multi tenant, logically separated; dedicated storage (happy medium) and pick region, or custom-managed keys.  This application offers configurable data retention periods.  Data deletion can be set from no retention to indefinite retention.  This application is GDPR compliant.

Harvey.AI does not use MCP servers.

Regarding the Harvey for Word add-in:
The Harvey Word Add-In allows users to modify Word documents by editing existing text or adding new content. Suggestions can be generated through user prompts or by analyzing uploaded precedents to identify relevant clauses.

The add-in follows the same stringent security and data privacy standards as the Harvey web application, including ISO 27001 certification and SOC 2 Type II compliance.

Harvey's Word Add-In is a web-based extension built with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. It leverages Harvey’s secure platform infrastructure for processing.  Harvey's Word Add-In only accesses the content in the document the user currently has open. It cannot access other documents on the user's device, or other files owned by their company or colleagues within Microsoft 365.

When making revisions: The add-in processes only the text explicitly highlighted by the user and any content uploaded as precedent.
When drafting new content: Harvey looks at 50 characters before and after the cursor, to provide context for formatting and language, though it's limited to examining the current paragraph only. Access to the document ends when the document is closed or the add-in is exited. Users must activate the Word Add-In separately for each document they wish to use Harvey with.  The Add-In utilizes the same infrastructure as Harvey’s web application.

The Add-In applies the same encryption standards as the Harvey web application:
Data in Transit: Secured using HTTPS and TLS 1.2 or higher to ensure protection during transmission.
Data at Rest: Encrypted with AES-256 or higher, providing strong security for stored data.
The Harvey Word Add-In uses the same authentication method configured for your Harvey workspace. Users log in with their Harvey credentials, including single sign-on (SSO) via SAML.  To access the Add-In, users must also have specific permissions granted by the Delta administrators to manage Add-In permissions directly through the Harvey web application.  All activity within the Harvey Word Add-In is visible to your organization’s Harvey administrators through the Workspace History and Usage dashboards.  Additionally, this activity is streamed to the History and Audit Log API endpoints, enabling programmatic tracking and integration with Delta's internal systems.  the Word Add-In will be deployed using Radia

Regarding the Harvey for Outlook Add-In:
Harvey for Outlook lets you access Harvey Assistant directly within an email thread. You can generate answers by asking open-ended questions or by uploading precedent documents from your desktop or Vault (Vault is a collaborative workspace for large-scale document review, analysis, and synthesis).

Harvey for Outlook only has access to the currently open email thread. It does not scan your entire inbox or any other part of Outlook. Harvey does not automatically read your emails; it only has context of the current thread when you hit “Ask”.

When asking questions: Harvey uses the context of the open thread and its attachments.
When saving to Vault: Harvey will save the current email thread and its attachments to Vault.
Once the thread is closed or Harvey for Outlook is exited, access to that email ends.  

Harvey for Outlook utilizes the same infrastructure as Harvey’s web application for processing data. Harvey for Outlook maintains the same encryption standards as the Harvey web application:

Data in transit: Secured using HTTPS and TLS 1.2 or higher to ensure protection during transmission.
Data at rest: Encrypted with AES-256 or higher, providing strong security for stored data.

Authentication is the same as your Harvey workspace:

Users log in with their Harvey credentials, including single sign-on (SSO) via SAML (if enabled).
Access also requires Add-In permissions granted by Harvey, even after downloading it. Admins should work with their Harvey Customer Success Manager to designate which team members should have access. 

Harvey for Sharepoint/OneDrive:
Users are able to find and upload SharePoint files directly in the Harvey App using a standard OAuth flow.  Harvey for SharePoint uses delegated access (Mike Ramirez said this is possible) to interact with Microsoft Graph API on behalf of a user, meaning it requires both the application and the user to have the necessary permissions. Admin users can access the "Integrations" section in the Harvey App Settings panel to manage workspace integrations.  Once an admin enables an integration, all users in that workspace will see “Upload from SharePoint/OneDriveˮ buttons in Assistant.  When an integration is disabled, all user access tokens for that integration will be cleared from the workspace. This is to ensure that Harvey doesnʼt have access to the customerʼs DMS once the integration is disabled. Additionally, users will need to re-authenticate and reconnect their Harvey accounts if and when the integration is re-enabled. Also, when an integration is disabled, files previously uploaded via the integration will remain in Harvey and just follow the workspace's standard data retention policies. 

The Harvey SharePoint integration utilizes Microsoftʼs OAuth 2.0 protocol for secure and authorized access to SharePoint resources. OAuth 2.0 is an industry-standard authorization framework that allows applications like Harvey to obtain limited access to user accounts on an HTTP service. 

All files uploaded from SharePoint will also follow your workspace's existing standard data retention policies. Documents uploaded from SharePoint are stored securely within Harvey's infrastructure, adhering to our strict data protection standards. The Harvey SharePoint integration maintains the same robust security and infrastructure protocols as the core Harvey app, ensuring all existing security measures, infrastructure, and data protection standards remain intact.

column1: Shared Infrastructure Component AI Account AWS (Gen AI Pattern - Summarization Service)
column9:
The Enterprise AI and CCoE teams are collaborating to develop a suite of Generative AI Patterns on AWS to be consumed by other teams across Delta. These patterns will provide modular, reusable building blocks that can be integrated into their projects without deep AI/ ML expertise.​
This STR is for the 'Summarization Service' pattern:
Summarization Pattern - To enable users to receive concise summaries of their documents​.

The Patterns will be published to AWS Service Catalog.
column40:
As demand for Generative AI solutions grows across the organization, multiple teams are experimenting independently with similar AI use cases — such as text summarization and conversational interfaces.
This results in duplicated effort, inconsistent security configurations, and lack of standardization in the AI solutions.
To address this, the Generative AI Patterns portfolio intends to provide pre-approved, production-ready templates (published through AWS Service Catalog) that allow teams to quickly deploy standard AI capabilities in their own AWS accounts.
The Summarization pattern is one such standard product that will allow users to receive concise summaries of their text documents.
column41:
Standardization: Establishes a single, AWS-supported framework for agentic AI development.
Future-proofing: Maintains compatibility with Amazon Bedrock and other AWS services.
Faster delivery: Reduces time spent on boilerplate orchestration code.
Cost efficiency: No licensing costs; reduces redundant engineering effort.
Governance: Confidence in long-term support from AWS compared to other third-party solutions.
column42:
Summarization Service Pattern:
Enables automated summarization of long-form content such as reports, customer feedback, support tickets, customer call transcripts, or knowledge articles.
Allows teams to quickly generate concise summaries for faster decision-making and improved productivity.

column51:
Support model:
Teams involved:
•	Enterprise AI (Pattern owners)
•	CCoE
•	Foundations team (Service Catalog maintenance)
•	Consumer teams (Tenant account owners)
Model approach:
•	Self-service support – ZAP documentation with descriptions, detailed steps, FAQs etc. published by the pattern owners (AI team).
•	Deployment support - Issues related to the pattern’s deployment templates or bugs will be handled by the AI team, raised by the consumer teams via Teams channel.
•	AWS – Platform issues will be escalated by consumer teams to AWS support
•	Releases and Updates - Updates or new pattern versions will be published to the Service Catalog by the pattern owner team after validation in DEV and SI environments.
•	Monitoring and maintenance – The consumer teams are responsible for regular maintenance of the solutions deployed to their respective accounts. They can choose to set up any monitoring other than the basic out-of-the-box system-health CloudWatch dashboards that come with the patterns.
column53:
The introduction of the Generative AI Patterns will have a low operational impact but will enhance the organization’s AI delivery capability through standardization and automation.
1. Skills Impact
Minimal new skill requirements - Consumer teams only need basic familiarity with AWS Service Catalog and how to provide input parameters (no deep infrastructure expertise required).
Upskilling opportunity - Teams gain exposure to using AWS-native AI services like Amazon Bedrock, Lambda etc.
2. Tooling Impact - No new tools required. The patterns use existing AWS platform tools (Service Catalog, CloudFormation/CDK, CloudWatch)
3. Owners - Pattern owners - Enterprise AI team
Governance Consultation - CCoE
Service Catalog maintenance - Foundations team
Deployment and maintenance of solution - Individual consumer teams

This standardized, production-ready template enables teams to quickly deploy AI capabilities in their own AWS account, reducing duplicated effort, improving security, and ensuring consistent architecture.

This approach accelerates delivery while maintaining control, scalability, and alignment across teams.

column9: Whitelist S3 Tables globally across ALL active AWS accounts, including, tera-edw-dvl (Acc Num: 037661190395) and crew-ai (Acc Num: 724772081708)
column25: Requesting to provision AWS S3 tables across all accounts in Delta
column40:
tera-edw Current Use Case:  
The FAM (Flight Advisory Message) Timeliness Queue is used to analyze when late arriving equipment problems occur and how long it takes OCC SOMs to solution the problem by issuing an ETD FAM or aircraft swap. This dataset also shows how the effective turn time of a flight changes over time and can be analyzed to find improvements to make ETD FAMs more accurate and timely after the problem is first flagged. Timely advisories allow flight crews and ground operations to adjust plans quickly and keeps customers accurately informed on the status of their flight. 
The current FAM Timeliness Queue is provided by a view in dwprod but will have decreasing performance over time since it queries and joins inbound and outbound flights dating back to 2023. Access to S3 tables will allow for a seamless flow of data through an ETL on AWS that will maintain a permanent data store for the FAM Timeliness Queue in dwprod. 

crew-ai Current Use Case: 
We have data services that run continuously to fetch tc-engine, pilot supply, open time and reserves by day. These services fetch the near real time data that needs to be saved as snapshots on each run. The results from each run require querying at a given point in time for analytics and time travel. The current process of converting time series data in pseudo temporal data requires significant undertaking and logic that can be simplified through S3 tables. Since S3 Tables provide in-built iceberg support to auto capture snapshots, we can pair this with Athena for time travel and point in time queries to visualize in BI tools such as quicksight.
column41:
Whitelisting S3 Tables would allow Data Engineers an easy way to create, maintain, and store Apache Iceberg tables. This would increase efficiency on projects that could benefit from using an Iceberg table by reducing the amount of ongoing effort need to create automated maintenance processes of manually maintain Iceberg tables stored in AWS.  
Iceberg tables increase performance by allowing maintenance operations, so table read speed does not decrease over time. Iceberg tables also allow for time travel to retrieve valid records from different valid states of a table enabling the storage of pseudo temporal data in an accessible AWS table.
column42:
Create and maintain Apache Iceberg tables without managing additional maintenance operations like vacuuming and compaction. Apache Iceberg allows for snapshot time travel and optimized performance by removing expired records. 
S3 tables provide optimized storage for analytics workload by combining the benefits of the Apache Iceberg open table format and ease of use of S3 buckets with an Athena connection. S3 tables can be configured to automatically run maintenance operations on Iceberg tables including vacuuming, snapshot expiry, and compaction.
column43: Data will be stored in S3 objects and S3 Tables
column44: There are currently no other Delta approved products that offer automatic maintenance of Apache Iceberg tables or any other open table format.
column45: Other options include continuing to use an Apache Iceberg table in S3 but find alternative method to maintain the table and finding an alternate intermediate data store for the ETL.
